(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1983 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and the 1984 Term is now commenced."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-1611. Peter Walton, Appellant v. Alaska Bar Association. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 83–1814. Volkswagen of America, Inc., Appellant v. Superior
Court of California, City and County of San Francisco (Joan Nosse,
et al., Real Parties in Interest). Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 83-1979. Dennis M. Perruccio, Appellant v. Connecticut. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 83-2029. Safe Water Foundation of Texas, et al., Appellants v.
City of Houston. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, First
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 83-2168. Ruel A. Galbreath, Appellant v. School Board of
Broward County, Florida, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 83–6510. L. C., Appellant v. Florida Department of Health and
Rehabilitative Services. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, Second District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.

21
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
No. 84–40. Leo J. Talikka, etc., Appellant v. Department of Mental
Health and Mental Retardation, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Ohio, Lake County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 84-43. Good Samaritan Hospital of Maryland, Inc., Appellant v.
Maryland, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Maryland. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–66. Wine and Spirits Specialty, Inc., Appellant v. Edward D.
Daniel, Director, Department of Public Safety, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 84-98. Benjamin Allen Pope, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth Supreme Judicial District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–126. Victor Perella, Appellant v. New Jersey. Appeal from
the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–134. Peter J. Coruzzi, Appellant v. New Jersey, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–137. Susan E. Davidson, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–152. Henry Brewer, et al., Appellants v. City of Winston-
Salem, N.C., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of North Caro-
lina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–156. Macon Association for Retarded Citizens, Appellant v.
Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 84–158. Rocky B. Fisheries, Inc., et al., Appellants v. North
Bend Fabrication & Machine, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 84–167. Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, Appellant v. Fran-
chise Tax Board of California. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.

..
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
3
No. 84-221. Robert E. Henshaw, et ux., et al., Appellants v. State
Tax Commission of Michigan, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 84-5221. Richard Evans, et ux., etc., Appellants v. Harley
Hotels, Inc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 83–1770. Delta Marine Contractors, Inc., Appellant v. Avondale
Shipyards, Inc. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 83–1790. Mississippi River Transmission Corporation, Appellant
v. George B. Simonton, etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisi-
ana, Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83–1955. Donald J. Harman, Appellant v. La Crosse Tribune,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District IV. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 83-1997. John C. Amis, Jr., Appellant v. City of Fort Myers,
Florida, et al. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Sec-
ond District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83-2037. City of Lambertville, Apppellant v. Lambertville
Policemen's Association. Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jer-
sey, Appellate Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83-2068. Donald E. Gann, Appellant v. San Jose City Council,
et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of California, County of Santa
Clara. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 83-2074. Hazel A. Hester, Appellant v. Department of Health
and Human Services. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
for the Federal Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83-2138. Citizens Federal Savings and Loan Association of Day-
ton, Ohio, Appellant v. Van W. Page, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Ohio, Warren County. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83-2149. Edward Dobreff, et ux., Appellants v. Township of
Harrison. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83-2157. Crane Neck Association, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
NYC/Long Island County Services Group, et al. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83-5907. Charles Iseley, Sr., Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 83–6272. Nonna Osipova, Appellant v. Fred Brooks, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 83–6479. Willie Lane Alexander, Jr., Appellant v. Tennessee.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 83-6670. Nellie Washington Roy, et al., Appellants v. City of
Middletown. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Butler County.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 83-6803. Charles Arty George, Appellant v. Houston Police De-
partment, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

District of Texas. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 83–1893. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Appel-
lant v. Martin Industries, Inc. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 83-1938. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Appel-
lant v. Westinghouse Electric Corp. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84–63. Frederick L. Jerry, Appellant v. General Motors Cor-
poration, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 84–176. Utility Consulting Services, Inc., Appellant v. City of
San Juan. Appeal from the Supreme Court for the Commonwealth of
Puerto Rico. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84-5280. Edward Matkovcik, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 83-2046. Joseph Berry, Appellant v. Michigan Racing Commis-
sioner. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 84–147. Rita Miller, et al., Appellants v. California Commission
on the Status of Women. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Third Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Doremus v. Board of Education, 342 U.S. 429 (1952).
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–976. California, Petitioner v. Roscoe Howard, Jr. The petition
for rehearing is granted. The order entered April 30, 1984 denying the
petition for writ of certiorari is vacated. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appellate District, for further
consideration in light of California v. Beheler, 463 U.S. (1983).

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
7
Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens
dissent.
No. 83-1691. John R. Block, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Ronald E. Payne, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Heckler v. Community
Health Services of Crawford County, Inc., 467 U.S. (1984).
-
.
No. 83–1818. United States, Petitioner v. Donna Hylin, Individually
and as Administrator of the Estate of Donald Hylin, Deceased. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
United States v. S.A. Empresa de Viacao Aerea Rio Grandense (Varig
Airlines), 467 U.S. (1984).
-
No. 84–120. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Petitioners v. Michigan Academy of Family Physicians,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Heckler v. Ringer, 466 U.S. (1984).

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 84-5029. Eugene Paleno, Appellant v. Robert C. Quinn, etc. The
motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Appellant is allowed until October 22, 1984, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a statement as to
jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983),
we would dismiss the appeal for want of jurisdiction and, treating the
papers whereon the appeal would be taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, we would deny certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
-

of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Appellant
is allowed until October 22, 1984, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a statement as to jurisdiction in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
-
13
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would
dismiss the appeal for want of jurisdiction and, treating the papers
whereon the appeal would be taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
we would deny certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to
proceed in forma pauperis.

probable jurisdiction is noted. The cases are consolidated and a total of
one hour is allotted for oral argument.

Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, et al.; and
No. 83-1633. Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company,
et al., Appellants v. National Railroad Passenger Corporation. Appeals
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. In
No. 83-1492 probable jurisdiction is noted. In No. 83-1633 further con-
sideration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of
the case on the merits. The cases are consolidated and a total of one
hour is allotted for oral argument.

pellants v. Western Oil and Gas Association, et al. Appeal from the

tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Rhode Island denied.
No. 84–5082. Garnett W. Brown, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania, et al.
The motion of Harvey Kudler for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
COMMON LAW CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 83-2056. In Re C. Itoh & Company (America) Inc., Petitioner.
Petition for common law of certiorari denied.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 83-6893. In Re Clovis Carl Green, Jr., Petitioner; and
No. 84-5023. In Re Charles Jess Palmer, Petitioner. The petitions for
writ of habeas corpus are denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 83-2055. In Re C. Itoh & Company (America) Inc., Petitioner;
No. 83-6707. In Re J. Patrick Dohm, Petitioner;
No. 83-6842. In Re J. Patrick Dohm, Petitioner;
No. 83-6976. In Re Raymond H. Acosta, Petitioner;
No. 83-7003. In Re Samuel L. Sommer, Petitioner; and

82
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984
No. 84-5243. In Re Sylvester Jones, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
mandamus are denied.
No. 83-2094. In Re Ruth Ellen Pearce, Petitioner. The petition for a
writ of mandamus and other relief is denied.
No. 84-5021. In Re Terry Louis Carter, Petitioner. Petition for writ
of mandamus and/or prohibition is denied.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 83-6897. In Re Marsha M. Barritt, Petitioner. Petition for writ
of prohibition is denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1984
93
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83–1816. William Jibson, Appellant v. White Cloud Education
Association. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Black-
mun, Justice Rehnquist and Justice Stevens would note probable juris-
diction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 83-7039. Robert Chambers, Appellant v. Vermont. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-245. Mary D. Pellegrino, et al., Appellants v. William A.
O'Neill, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 84-293. John Ferneding, Appellant v. Consolidated Rail Cor-
poration, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 84-5217. Beatrice L. Robinson, Appellant v. Governor James
Thompson, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-278. Clyde F. Stagner, dba West Route Trading Company,
Appellant v. Wyoming State Tax Commission, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.

94
-
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1984
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. George Onett, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file the petition for writ of certiorari that does not
comply with the Rules of this Court is denied.
No. . Tropigas, S. A., Petitioner v. Richard Anderson, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition for writ of certiorari that
does not comply with the Rules of this Court is denied.
-
No. -. National Association for the Advancement of Colored Peo-
ple and Perry White, Appellants v. Town of Hilton Head, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file the jurisdicational statement that does
not comply with the Rules of this Court is denied. Justice Stevens and
Justice O'Connor would grant the motion.
No. A-178. William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator, United States
Environmental Protection Agency, Applicant v. Union Carbide Agri-
cultural Products Co., Inc., et al. The application for stay presented to
Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court is granted and the
District Court's judgment in 79 Civ. 2913 (RO) enjoining operation of
Section 3(c)(1)(D) is stayed pending disposition of the appeal.
No. A-214. Henry N. Walters, Administrator of Veteran's Affairs, et
al., Applicants v. National Association of Radiation Survivors, et al.
The motion to vacate the stay entered by Justice Rehnquist on Septem-
ber 27, 1984 is denied. Justice Stevens would grant the motion.
No. D-444. In the Matter of Disbarment of William C. Sherr. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. 82–1922. Southern Motor Carriers Rate Conference, Inc., et al.,
Petitioners v. United States. The motion of National Industrial Trans-
portation League for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 83–703. Florida Power & Light Company, Petitioner v. Joette
Lorion, etc., et al.; and
No. 83-1031. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission and
United States, Petitioners v. Joette Lorion, et al. The motion of the
Solicitor General to permit Charles A. Rothfeld, Esquire, to present
oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 83–1020. Ohio, Petitioner v. William Lee Kovacs, dba B & W En-
terprises, et al. The motion of Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bank-
ruptcy of Quanta Resources Corporation, Debtor, for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae, out-of-time is denied. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1984
95
No. 83-1035. Tennessee, Appellant v. Cleamtee Garner, etc., et al.;
and
No. 83-1070. Memphis Police Department, et al., Petitioners v.
Cleamtee Garner, etc., et al. The motion of appellant in No. 83–1035
and petitioners in No. 83–1070 for divided argument is granted.
No. 83-1097. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Sandra Turner, et al. The motion of State re-
spondents for leave to file reply brief in support of petitioner is denied.
No. 83-1836. Melvin M. Burton, Jr., Petitioner v. Board of Profes-
sional Responsibility of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 83-2076. Roger Pollard, Petitioner v. Board of Police Commis-
sioners and Norman A. Caron. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 84–322. Charles G. Reminick, et al., Petitioners v. Jack Maltz, et
al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing
the views of the United States.
No. 84–372. Alan Friedrich, Petitioner v. United States. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Powell and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. 84-5266. Maxine Denise Wynne Chambers, Petitioner v. Ameri-
can Greetings Corporation. The motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October
30, 1984, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissent-
ing: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S.
(1983), we would deny the petition for writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 84-5340. Larry R. Cummings, Petitioner v. Merit Systems Pro-
tection Board. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 30, 1984, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983),
we would deny the petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 84-76. Nell Hunter, et al., etc., Appellants v. Victor Underwood
and Carmen Edwards, etc. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted.
No. 84–231. Alvin D. Hooper and Mary N. Hooper, Appellants v.
Bernalillo County Assessor. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
Mexico. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 84–237. Yolanda Aguilar, et al., Appellants v. Betty-Louise
Felton, et al.;
No. 84–238. Secretary, United States Department of Education, Ap-
pellant v. Betty-Louise Felton, et al.; and
No. 84-239. Chancellor of the Board of Education of City of New
York, Appellant v. Betty-Louise Felton, et al. Appeals from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Further consideration
of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the cases on
the merits. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted
for oral argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

tioners v. Klamath Indian Tribe. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

Indians, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

Tax Commission, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of South Carolina granted.

al. The motion of Legal Foundation of America for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of National Association of In-
dependent Insurers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas granted.
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions and this petition.

Petitioner v. Pueblo of Santa Ana. The motion of Atchison, Topeka and

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 15, 1984 until
Monday, October 29, 1984.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1984
117
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-253. Linwood E. Briley, Applicant v. E. L. Booker, Warden.
The application for stay of execution, which is scheduled for 11 p. m. on
Friday, October 12, 1984, presented to the Chief Justice and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
dissenting: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all cir-
cumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and
Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U. S. 153, 227, 231
(1976), we would grant the application for stay, a petition for writ of
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1984
119
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-461. Club Mediterranee, S. A., Appellant v. Marjorie
Schlossberg Dorin and Philip Dorin. Appeal from the Appellate Divi-
sion, Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83–396. United States, Petitioner v. Gilbert Moreno. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Segura v. United States, 468 U. S. (1984). Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice White and Justice Stevens dissent.
-
_

Court is denied.

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 84-271. Illinois, et al., Petitioners v. Associated Milk Producers,
Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Justice Stevens took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 84-294. Envirotech Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Amstar
Corporation. The motion of Simmons Fastener Corporation for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit denied.
No. 84-5213. Rueben Palmer, Petitioner v. Richard DeRobertis,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Justice White took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 84-5566. Earnest Knighton, Jr., Petitioner v. Louisiana. The
application for stay presented to Justice White and by him referred to
the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall, dissenting: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in
all circumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the
Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153,
227, 231 (1976), we would grant the application for stay, the petition
for writ of certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 84-5450. In Re Delano Benjamin Harris, Petitioner. The petition
for writ of habeas corpus is denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984
145
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 83-6904. Mark Steven Collier, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Texas, Third Supreme Judicial District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon.
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 84-319. Allan Falk, Appellant v. State Bar of Michigan. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-408. Clear-View Cable T. V., Inc., Appellant v. Town of Nar-
rows. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-5379. Raymond L. Medlin, Appellant v. James T. Poulson, et
ux., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-5380. Frank A. Summa, Appellant v. James Hasson, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 84–131. Intake Water Company, Appellant v. Yellowstone River
Compact Commission, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Montana. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 84–196. Rosemary Furman, dba Northside Secretarial Service,
Appellant v. The Florida Bar. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Flor-
ida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

146
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984
No. 84–342. Fireside Chrysler-Plymouth, Mazda, Inc., et al., Appel-
lants v. Jim Edgar, Secretary of State of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 84-361. David E. Kempner, Appellant v. Dearborn Local 2077,
City of Dearborn Supervisory, Technical and Professional Employees,
AFSCME, AFL-CIO, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Mich-
igan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–5421. Leo Thompson, Appellant v. Arkansas Social Services.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–315. Leonard G. Leverson, Appellant v. William H. Conway,
Commissioner, Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Justice White, Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-2082. Michael Alan Crooker, Petitioner v. United States Pa-
role Commission. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of the Solicitor General's present interpretation of Fed.
R. Crim. P. 32 asserted in his brief filed October 3, 1984, on behalf of
the Parole Commission.
No. 84-346. Barry Mintzes, Warden, Petitioner v. Roy Wilson. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Strickland v. Washington, 466 U. S. (1984).
-

No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. The motion of Alabama for divided argument is granted.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. D-446. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Lee Winner. David
Lee Winner, of Wooster, Ohio, having requested to resign as a member
of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from
the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September 18, 1984, is
hereby discharged.
No. 82-1260. Copperweld Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Inde-
pendence Tube Corporation. The motion of respondent for Court to
enter order providing for nonretroactive application of judgment and
other relief is denied. Justice White took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 83–1329. Joseph Ponte, Superintendent, Massachusetts Correc-
tional Institution, Walpole, Petitioner v. John Real. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is
granted.
No. 83–1894. Pattern Makers' League of North America, AFL-CIO,
et al., Petitioners v. National Labor Relations Board, et al. The motion.
of the parties to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.

148
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984
No. 83-2165. Pamela D. Jones and Jennifer L. Dodge, etc., Petition-
ers v. Michael Petit, Commissioner, Maine Department of Human Serv-
ices. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 84–231. Alvin D. Hooper and Mary N. Hooper, Appellants v.
Bernalillo County Assessor. The motion of the parties to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 84-5004. Truman Lewis Ball, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Jo S.
Widener, Esq., of Bristol, Virginia, is appointed to serve as counsel for
the petitioner in this case.
No. 84-5495. Judy S. Weems, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until November 19, 1984, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would deny the
petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.

Massachusetts. In these cases probable jurisdiction is noted. The cases
are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

159
No. 84-5334. Anson Avery Maynard, Petitioner v. North Carolina.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Carolina.
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 84-5349. Ronald Eugene Rickman, Petitioner v. Tennessee. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Ten-
nessee, Western Division, denied. Dissenting statement by Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 84-5351. Karu Gene White, Petitioner v. Kentucky. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 83-6943. Warren A. Wilkes, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White. Justice
Blackmun would grant certiorari and summarily affirm the judgment of
the Court of Appeals.
No. 84-6. Sailor J. Kennedy, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied. Justice White, joined by Justice Brennan, dissenting
from the denial of certiorari: Because the decision of the Court of Ap-
peals in this case conflicts with the decision of the Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit in United States v. Canus, 595 F. 2d 73 (1979), I would
grant certiorari.
No. 84-265. California, Petitioner v. Lee Edward Harris. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California denied.
No. 84–290. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, Petitioner v. Carol
Lynn Wooderson. The motion of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Associ-
ation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and
this petition.
No. 84-331. Dorothy Enright, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Board of
School Directors of the City of Milwaukee, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin denied. Justice White and
Justice O'Connor would deny the petition for writ of certiorari for want
of jurisdiction.
No. 84-365. Esther Garcia Manas Perez, Administratrix of the Es-
tate of Rosa Maria Manas Y Pineiro, Deceased, Petitioner v. Chase
Manhattan Bank, N. A. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeals of New York denied. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari.

160
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984
No. 84-382. James N. Fleming, Petitioner v. W. Bedford Moore, III.
The motion of respondent for award of attorney's fees is denied. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia denied. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion
and this petition.
No. 84-5247. James David Raulerson, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The petition for
a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit is denied. Justice Brennan, dissenting: Adhering to my
view that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual
punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments,
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U. S. 153, 227 (1976), I would grant certiorari
and vacate the death sentence in this case. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Marshall.
No. 84-5350. Frederick Maxwell, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, East-
ern District, denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Brennan joins.
No. 84-5362. Alan Humphrey, Petitioner v. Southern Continental
Bell Telephone Company, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 84-5377. Theresa Mulqueen Skeeter, Petitioner v. City of Suf-
folk, Virginia. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 84-5648. Thomas A. Barefoot, Petitioner v. Raymond K. Pro-
cunier, Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White and
by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is de-
nied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our
views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual
punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments,
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U. S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant the
application for stay, the petition for a writ of certiorari and vacate the
death sentence in this case.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 84–479. In Re Mobil Oil Corporation, et al., Petitioners. The pe-
tition for writ of mandamus is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984
REHEARINGS DENIED
161
No. 83-6916. Daniel K. Johnson, Petitioner v. Raymond K. Pro-
cunier, Director, Texas Department of Corrections, et al.;
No. 83-7016. Burton R. Landes, Petitioner v. William French Smith,
Attorney General, of the United States, et al.; and
No. 84-5203. Mary Alice Consuello Mills McLaine, Petitioner v. Spiro
Agnew, et al. The petitions for rehearing are denied.
No. 83-623. Frank B. James, et al., Petitioners v. William P. Clark,
Secretary of the Interior, et al. The motion for leave to file a petition
for rehearing is denied.
No. 83-6829. Timothy C. Palmes, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The applications to sus-
pend the effect of the order denying the petition for a writ of certiorari
and for stay of execution of sentence of death are denied. The petition
for rehearing is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissent-
ing: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances
cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth
Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U. S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we
would grant the applications and the petition for rehearing, vacate the
order denying certiorari, and would grant the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari and would vacate the death sentence in this case.

Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-342. Earnest Knighton, Jr., Applicant v. Frank C. Blackburn,
Warden, Louisiana State Penitentiary. The application for stay of ex-
ecution of sentence of death presented to Justice White and by him re-
ferred to the Court is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall,
dissenting: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all cir-
cumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and
Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U. S. 153, 227, 231
(1976), we would grant the application for stay, a petition for writ of
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1984
175
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-243. Marengo County Commission, et al., Appellants v.
United States. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-412. Home Builders and Contractors Association of Palm
Beach County, Inc., etc., et al., Appellants v. Board of County Com-
missioners of Palm Beach County, et al. Appeal from the District Court
of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83–1593. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Petitioner v. Frank Kuehner, et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. The motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment
is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit to be remanded to the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania with instructions to: (1)
remand the cases of the named respondents to the Secretary for review
pursuant to Section 2(d)(2)(C) of the Social Security Disability Benefits
Reform Act of 1984; (2) make any necessary clarifications in the defini-
tion and scope of the class; (3) remand the cases of the unnamed class
members to the Secretary for proceedings pursuant to Section 2(d)(3) of
that Act; and (4) take other actions appropriate in light of that Act.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-272. Alwin E. Hopfmann, Applicant v. United States Federal
Election Commission, et al. The application for stay addressed to Jus-
tice O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied.

176
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1984
No. A-277. The Daily Pantagraph, et al., Applicants v. Richard M.
Baner, Judge, Circuit Court of Woodford County, Illinois, et al. The
application for stay of a juvenile court order presented to Justice
Stevens and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join.
No. A-279. Thomas L. Schuchman, et ux., Applicants v. United
States. The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-443. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Earl Dizak. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-457. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alfred Bruce Shapiro.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-461. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marvin J. Powers. It is
ordered that Marvin J. Powers, of Dallas, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-727. Lamar Alexander, Governor of the State of Tennessee,
et al., Petitioners v. Hershel Choate, et al. The motion of respondents
for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 83–1748. Allis-Chalmers Corporation, Petitioner v. Roderick S.
Lueck. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is or-
dered that Gerald S. Boisits, Esquire, of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, is ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 83-1950. Mary Jean McAllister and Judith E. Kline, Petitioners
v. Gulf Federal Savings and Loan Association. The motion of respond-
ent for taxation of costs and attorney's fees is denied.
No. 83-6881. Murray O. Bradford, Petitioner v. Almetta N. Brad-
ford. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 84-129. Reavis & McGrath, Petitioners v. Frank P. Antinore,
et al. The motion of respondents Jones, et al. to direct the Clerk to file
an application for extension of time to file a cross-petition for writ of
certiorari and that such cross-petition be considered irrespective of
dispostion of the opening petition for writ of certiorari is denied.
No. 84-321. Alabama, Petitioner v. Earnest James Sturdivant. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.

1
1
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1984
177
No. 84-5092. John Earl Booker, Petitioner v. Mississippi. The re-
spondent is requested to file a response to the petition for rehearing
within thirty days.
No. 84-5407. Samuel J. Gemelli, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until November 26, 1984, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would deny the
petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.

Carmouche for the respondent.
No. 83-935. United States, Petitioner v. John Clyde Abel. Argued by
Mr. Stephen S. Trott for the petitioner and by Ms. Yolanda Barrera
Gomez for the respondent.
No. 83–5424. Glen Burton Ake, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Argued by
Mr. Arthur B. Spitzer for the petitioner and by Mr. Michael C. Turpen
for the respondent.
No. 83-1158. Estate of Donald E. Thornton and Connecticut, Peti-
tioners v. Caldor, Inc. Argued by Mr. Nathan Lewin for the petitioner,
Estate of Donald E. Thornton, by Mr. Joseph I. Lieberman for the
petitioner, State of Connecticut, and by Mr. Paul Gewirtz for the
respondent.
☑
Adjourned until Tuesday, November 13, 1984 at 10 o'clock.
No. A-360. Timothy C. Palmes, Applicant v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application for stay

192
WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1984
of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Powell and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall, dissenting: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all
circumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227,,
231 (1976), we would grant the application for stay, a petition for writ of
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1984
193
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 84-5717. Alvin R. Moore, Petitioner v. Ross Maggio, Jr., War-
den, et al. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is granted
pending the final disposition of the petition for a writ of certiorari.
Justice White and Justice Rehnquist dissent from the foregoing order.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1984
195
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-5687. Robert Lee Willie, Petitioner v. Ross Maggio, Jr.,
Warden. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall,
dissenting: Adhering to views that the death penalty is in all circum-
stances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and
Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231
(1976), we would grant the application for stay, the petition for writ of
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1984
197
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Powell, and Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 83–1367. Florida, Petitioner v. Damasco Vincente Rodriguez. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida,
Third District. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is reversed and case remanded to the District Court of Appeal for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam. Justice Marshall dissents. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan joins.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 83–1722. Mississippi Republican Executive Committee, Appel-
lant v. Owen H. Brooks, et al.;
No. 83-1865. Owen H. Brooks, et al., Appellants v. William A.
Allain, Governor of Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 83-2053. William A. Allain, et al., Appellants v. Owen H.
Brooks, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Mississippi. The judgment is affirmed. Concurring
opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist
with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 84-83. Gladys L. Trapf, Appellant v. Oscar Lohr, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–326. John T. Cain, Appellant v. New York. Appeal from the
Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial De-
partment. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 84–198. Louis E. Olivero, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from the
Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

denied.

No. 84-5059. Patrick Ramirez, Petitioner v. Indiana. The motion of
petitioner for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Kenneth F. Ripple, Esquire, of South Bend, Indiana, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 84-5268. Thelma P. Gordon, Petitioner v. Raymond J. Donovan,
Secretary of Labor, etc. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 4, 1984,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S.
(1983), we would deny the petition for writ of certiorari without reach-
ing the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
-
No. 84-5350. Frederick M. Maxwell, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. The
application to suspend the effect of the order denying certiorari pre-
sented to Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant the application.
No. 84-5506. Bernie J. E. Dingle, Appellant v. Calvin D. Simpkins,
etc. The application for stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred
to the Court is denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1984
217
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 83-1045. United States Department of Justice, et al., Petitioners
v. Anthony Provenzano; and
No. 83-5878. Alfred B. Shapiro and Gregory J. Wentz, Petitioners v.
Drug Enforcement Administration. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit and the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of respondent in
No. 83-1045 for summary affirmance of the judgment is denied. The
motion of petitioners in No. 83–5878 for summary reversal is denied.
The judgments are vacated and the cases are remanded to the Courts of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Dissenting statement by Justice Stevens in No. 83–1045. Opin-
ion per curiam.
No. 83–6775. Lillian Thompson, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Petitioner's
motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-349. Ellen Gibney, et al., Appellants v. Toledo Federation of
Teachers, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Lucas
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 84-640. Martha B. Gaunce, Appellant v. National Transportation
Safety Board and Federal Aviation Administration. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dis-

218
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1984
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84–5506. Bernie J. E. Dingle, Appellant v. Calvin D. Simpkins,
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84–366. Ray Bell Oil Company, Inc., Appellant v. New Mexico.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New Mexico. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84-499. Fred V. Sasso, Appellant v. Ram Property Manage-
ment, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–5459. J. E. W., Appellant, v. Estate of John Doe. Appeal
from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-335. Robert E. Lockwood and Mary Warren Lockwood, Ap-
plicants v. United States. The application for stay addressed to Justice
Blackmun and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-448. In the Matter of Disbarment of Willis Walter Holloway,
Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-462. In the Matter of Disbarment of James C. Collier. It is
ordered that James C. Collier, of Orlando, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-1362. Cleveland Board of Education, Petitioner v. James
Loudermill, et al.;
No. 83–1363. Parma Board of Education, Petitioner v. Richard Don-
nelly, et al.; and
No. 83-6392. James Loudermill, Petitioner v. Cleveland Board of
Education, et al. The motion of City Respondents in No. 83-6392 for
correction of caption and for divided argument is denied.
No. 83-5954. Wayne Lindahl, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel Man-
agement. The motion of Willard Bronger, et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae is granted. The motion of Margaret Cheeseman, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 83-6808. Eugene Dalton, Petitioner v. United States, et al. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Y

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1984
219
Petitioner is allowed until December 17, 1984, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. (1983), we would deny the
petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 84-28. Donald C. Brockett, Appellant v. Spokane Arcades, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 84-143. Kenneth Eikenberry, Attorney General of Washington,
et al., Appellants v. J-R Distributors, Inc., et al. The motion of Citi-
zens for Decency Through Law, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 84-248. Alfred Pino, Appellant v. District Court of the Second
Judicial District's Children's Court, etc. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 84-627. City Council of the City of Chicago, Petitioner v. Mars
Ketchum, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 84-483. Arkansas Public Service Commission, et al., Petitioners
v. Southwestern Bell Telephone Company. The Solicitor General is in-
vited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this order.
No. 84–494. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Machin-
ists Local 1327, International Association of Machinists, etc., et al. The
motion of respondents Lapinski, et al. to expedite consideration of this
case and No. 84-528, Lapinski v. Machinists Local 1327 and to consoli-
date with No. 83-1894, Pattern Makers' v. NLRB is denied.
No. 84–5029. Eugene Paleno, Appellant v. Robert C. Quinn, etc. The
motion of appellant for reconsideration of order denying leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 84-5108. Frank Liparota, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that William
T. Huyck, Esquire, of Chicago, Illinois, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 84-497. William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator, United States
Environmental Protection Agency, Appellant v. Union Carbide Agri-

220
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1984
cultural Products Co., et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York. In this case probable ju-
risdiction is noted. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-476. Robert McDonald, Petitioner v. David I. Smith. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 84–320. National Farmers Union Insurance Companies and
Lodge Grass School District No. 27, Petitioners v. Crow Tribe of In-
dians, et al. The motion of respondents LeRoy Sage and Flora Not
Afraid for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted.
No. 84-351. Atascadero State Hospital and California Department of
Mental Health, Petitioners v. Douglas James Scanlon. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted.
No. 84-465. Lee Roy Black, Director, Missouri Department of Cor-
rections and Human Resources and Dick D. Moore, Chairman, Missouri
Board of Probation and Parole, Petitioners v. Nicholas J. Romano. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit granted.
No. 84–501. Barry Mintzes, Warden, Petitioner v. Nealy Buchanon.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 35, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. States of
Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York,
New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South
Carolina, Georgia and Florida. Argued by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for
the plaintiff and by Mr. John G. Proudfit for the defendant State of
New York and Mr. J. Peter Doherty for the defendant State of Rhode
Island.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. Argued by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the plaintiff and by
Mr. Jim R. Bruce for the defendant State of Mississippi and Mr. Benja-
min Cohen for the defendant State of Alabama.
No. 82-1832. Town of Hallie, et al., Petitioners v. City of Eau Claire.
Argued by Mr. Claude J. Covelli for the petitioners and by Mr. Freder-
ick W. Fischer for the respondent.
No. 82-1922. Southern Motor Carriers Rate Conference, Inc., et al.,
Petitioners v. United States. Argued by Mr. Allen I. Hirsch for the
petitioners and by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1984
247
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-717. Richard C. Lussy, Appellant v. Mark S. Davidson, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-7034. Richard P. Viccarone, Petitioner v. Drug Enforcement
Administration, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment of the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit is vacated and the case is re-
manded to that court for reconsideration in light of Section 2(c) of the
Central Intelligence Information Act, Pub. L. 98-477,
and for such further proceedings as are indicated. See Shapiro v. Drug
Enforcement Administration, 469 U.S. (1984).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
Stat.
No. A-326. Edward Conrad Sawyer, Applicant v. United States. The
application for release pending appeal addressed to Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-463. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry W. Hopt. It is
ordered that Larry W. Hopt, of Seattle, Washington, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-464. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marlin K. McDaniel. It is
ordered that Marlin K. McDaniel, of Richmond, Indiana, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable

248
MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1984
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-465. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael A. Pelle. It is
ordered that Michael A. Pelle, of North Miami Beach, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-1545. Western Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Charles G. Cris-
well, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 83-1748. Allis-Chalmers Corporation, Petitioner v. Roderick S.
Lueck. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of the United States for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Ameri-
can Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 83–1785. Air France, Petitioner v. Valerie Hermien Saks. The
motion of International Air Transport Association for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of The Republic of
France for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 83-2146. Richard Wilson and Martin Vigil, Petitioners v. Gary
Garcia. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Steven G. Farber, Esquire, of Santa Fe, New Mexico, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 83-2166. Philip Q. Zauderer, Appellant v. Office of Disciplinary
Counsel of the Supreme Court of Ohio. The motion of American Civil
Liberties Union, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted.
No. 83-5424. Glen Burton Ake, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. The motion
of petitioner for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument is
granted.
No. 84–4. Williamson County Regional Planning Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City. The motion of National
Association of Counties, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted.
No. 84-28. Donald C. Brockett, Appellant v. Spokane Arcades, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 84–143. Kenneth Eikenberry, Attorney General of Washington,
et al., Appellants v. J-R Distributors, Inc., et al. The motion of Moral-
ity in Media, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1984
249
No. 84–205. Virginia Department of Conservation and Economic
Development, et al., Petitioners v. William P. Clark, Secretary of the
Interior, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 84-480. P.I.A. Asheville, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. North Caro-
lina, ex rel., Rufus Edmisten, Attorney General. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 84-5350. Frederick Maxwell, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. The re-
spondent is invited to file a response to the petition for rehearing within
thirty days.
No. 84-5564. Vojtech Dano, Petitioner v. Maria Szombathy. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until December 24, 1984, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would deny the
petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 84-5605. Moustafa Mohamed, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until December 24, 1984, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc. 464 U.S. - (1983), we would deny the
petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.

No. 83–1624. United States, Petitioner v. James Vincent Albertini.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

250
MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1984
the Ninth Circuit granted. In addition to the question presented in the
petition, the parties are requested to address the following question:
Whether the respondent's attendance at the "open house" at Hickam
Air Force Base on May 16, 1981, was the kind of reentry that Congress
intended to prohibit in 18 U. S. C. Section 1382?
No. 84–433. School Committee of the Town of Burlington, Massachu-
setts, et al., Petitioners v. Department of Education of the Common-
wealth of Massachusetts, et al. The petition for a writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit is granted lim-
ited to Questions I and V presented by the petition.
No. 84-5240. Maria Lucie Jean, et al., Petitioners v. Alan Nelson,
Commissioner, Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al. Motion
of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit granted.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1984
267
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 84-5332. Steven Smith, Petitioner v. Illinois. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ
of certiorari is granted. The judgment is reversed and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Illinois for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Powell
join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83–6673. Rodrigo Rodrigues, Appellant v. Hawaii. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 84-150. Wisconsin Elections Board, et al., Appellants v. Re-
publican Party of Wisconsin, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Wisconsin with instructions to dismiss the
complaint.
No. 84-603. George Freeman, Appellant v. Washington. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-658. Frontier Properties, etc., et al., Appellants v. Thomas
D. Elliott, etc., et al.; and John M. Ross, Appellant v. Standing Com-
mittee on Discipline, etc. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-

268
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1984
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–55. Employers National Insurance Company, Petitioner v.
Jorge Ochoa. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for
further consideration in light of Pub. L. 98-426.
No. 84-97. William B. Robinson, Former Commissioner of Bureau of
Corrections of Pennsylvania, et al., Petitioners v. Stanton Story, et al.,
etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of Pennhurst v. Halderman, 465 U.S. - (1984). Justice White, Jus-
tice Blackmun and Justice Stevens dissent.
No. 84–115. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Mario Lopez, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
motion of respondents Mario Lopez, et al. for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to be remanded to the United
States District Court for the Central District of California with instruc-
tions to: (1) remand the cases of the named respondents to the Secre-
tary for review pursuant to Section 2(d)(2)(C) of the Social Security
Disability Benefits Reform Act of 1984; (2) make any necessary clari-
fications in the definition and scope of the class; (3) remand the cases of
the unnamed class members to the Secretary for proceedings pursuant
to Section 2(d)(3) of that Act; and (4) take other actions appropriate in
light of that Act.
No. 84-5412. Raymond L. Lindsey, Petitioner v. United States Bu-
reau of Prisons, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further consideration in light of the Solicitor General's present inter-
pretation of Fed. R. Crim. P. 32 asserted in his brief filed November
14, 1984, on behalf of the respondents.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1984
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
269
No. A-417. Billy Joe Nichols, Applicant v. United States. The appli-
cation to recall and stay the mandate addressed to Justice Brennan and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-456. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francis Edward O'Brien.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-466. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bobby L. Hill. It is or-
dered that Bobby L. Hill, of Savannah, Georgia, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-467. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Allen McGlasson,
Jr.. It is ordered that Howard Allen McGlasson, Jr., of Savannah,
Georgia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-468. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence James
DiAngelus. It is ordered that Lawrence James DiAngelus, of Media,
Pennsylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. 79, Original. State of Oklahoma, Plaintiff v. State of Arkansas.
The motion of plaintiff to dismiss the bill of complaint is denied.
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. Donald T.
Regan, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. The Report of
Special Master on motion of the National Governors' Association for
leave to intervene is received and ordered filed.
No. 83–1368. Northwest Wholesale Stationers, Inc., Petitioner v. Pa-
cific Stationery and Printing Co. The motion of the Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.
No. 83–1492. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, Appellant v.
Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, et al.; and
No. 83–1633. Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company,
et al., Appellants v. National Railroad Passenger Corporation. The
motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument is granted.
