MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1984
No. 83–1673. Donald J. Devine, Director, Office of Personnel Man-
agement, Petitioner v. Allison E. Nutt, et al. The motion of the Solici-
tor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 83-2161. Montana, et al., Petitioners v. Blackfeet Tribe of Indi-
ans. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 84–4. Williamson County Regional Planning Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City. The motion of California,
et al. for leave to participate in oral argument as amici curiae, for di-
vided argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument
as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 84-48. United States, Petitioner v. Hughes Anderson Bagley.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Thomas W. Hillier, II, Esquire, of Seattle, Washington, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 84–68. Kerr-McGee Corporation, Petitioner v. Navajo Tribe of
Indians, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 84–262. Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company,
Petitioner v. Pueblo of Santa Ana. The motion of Public Service Com-
pany of New Mexico for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 84-438. Superintendent, Massachusetts Correctional Institution,
Walpole, Petitioner v. Gerald Hill and Joseph Crawford. The motion for
appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Jamie Ann
Sabino, Esq., of Wellesley, Massachusetts, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondents in this case.
No. 84–465. Lee Roy Black, Director, Missouri Department of Cor-
rections and Human Resources and Dick D. Moore, Chairman, Missouri
Board of Probation and Parole, Petitioners v. Nicholas J. Romano. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Jordan B. Cherrick, Esquire, of St. Louis, Missouri, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 84–851. Mobil Oil Corporation, et al., Applicants v. Dow Jones &
Company, Inc., et al. The application for stay or temporary injunctive
relief addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the Court is de-

nied. Justice Marshall, Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no

No. 83-935. United States, Petitioner v. John Clyde Abel. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 83-1307. United States, Petitioner v. Betty Lou Powell. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 83-6061. Jose Garcia and Francisco Garcia, Petitioners v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehn-
quist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 83–912. Edward Luce, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1984
287
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-445. Alpha Otis O'Daniel Stephens, Applicant v. Ralph Kemp,
Superintendent, Georgia Diagnostic & Classification Center. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting state-
ment by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting
statement by Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-5411. Edwin P. Wilson, Petitioner v. United States. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied.
REHEARING DENIED
No. 83-1845. Alpha Otis O'Daniel Stephens, Petitioner v. Ralph
Kemp, Superintendent, Georgia Diagnostic & Classification Center.
The petition for rehearing is denied. The supplementary application for
stay of execution of sentence of death is denied. Dissenting statement
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens would grant the supplementary application for
stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985
289
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 83-1947. United States, Petitioner v. Charles Noel Woodward.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Court of
Appeal's judgment reversing respondent's 18 U. S. C. Sec. 1001 con-
viction is reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-450. Central Jersey Industries, Inc., et al., Appellants v.-
United States Railway Association, et al. Appeal from the Special
Court, Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973. The judgment is
affirmed.
No. 84-720. George Deukmejian, Governor of the State of California,
et al., Appellants v. National Meat Association, et al. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The judgment is
affirmed.
No. 84–695. Gwendolyn L. King, etc., Appellant v. United States
District Court for the Central District of California, et al. (Integrity
Home Loan Co., Inc., et al., Real Parties in Interest). Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-766. John H. Jamason and James Gabbard, Appellants v.
Florida. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-733. David H. Rogers, Appellant v. North Carolina. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.

290
MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985
No. 84-828. National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People, Inc., etc., et al., Appellants v. Michael Roland Daniel, Lieu-
tenant Governor of South Carolina, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of South Carolina. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-1554. United States, Petitioner v. Richard DiMatteo, Morris
Kessler and James Suggs. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of
respondent Morris Kessler for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Luce v.
United States, 469 U. S. (1984). Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion and this case.
-
-
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . George W. Bonin, Petitioner v. American Airlines, Inc., et
al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
that does not comply with the Rules of this Court is denied.
No. . California and Public Utilities Commission of California,
Petitioner v. Federal Communications Commissioner, et al. The motion.
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is
denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. A-423. Donald L. Gold, Applicant v. United States. The applica-
tion for stay and/or bail addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. 79, Original. State of Oklahoma, Plaintiff v. State of Arkansas.
The Report of the Special Master is adopted. It is ordered that the par-
ties are directed to submit a proposed decree to the Special Master for
his approval and submission, together with any recommendations, to
this Court.
No. D-447. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Thornell. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-450. In the Matter of Disbarment of Erich Reisch. Disbarment
order entered.
No. D-460. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene Patrick Hines.
Disbarment order entered.

MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985
291
No. D-469. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren Douglas Uter-
mahlen. It is ordered that Warren Douglas Utermahlen, of Milford,
Pennsylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-470. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Alan Hayes. It is
ordered that Frank Alan Hayes, of San Antonio, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83–812. George C. Wallace, Governor of the State of Alabama,
et al., Appellants v. Ishmael Jaffree, et al.; and
No. 83–929. Douglas T. Smith, et al., Appellants v. Ishmael Jaffree,
et al. The motion of appellants in No. 83–929 for leave to file a supple-
mental brief after argument is granted.
No. 83–1329. Joseph Ponte, Superintendent, Massachusetts Correc-
tional Institution, Walpole, Petitioner v. John Real. The motion of
Barbara A. H. Smith, Esq., to permit Martin E. Levin, Esquire, to
present oral argument pro hac vice on behalf of petitioner is granted.
No. 83–1569. Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Petitioner v. Soler
Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc.; and
No. 83–1733. Soler Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc., Petitioner v. Mitsubishi
Motors Corporation. The motion of International Chamber of Com-
merce for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion
of American Arbitration Association for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae in No. 83-1569 is granted.
No. 83-1673. Donald J. Devine, Director, Office of Personnel Man-
agement, Petitioner v. Allison E. Nutt, et al. The motion of the Solic-
itor General to permit Charles A. Rothfeld, Esquire, to present oral
argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 83–1750. United States, Petitioner v. James Rual Miller. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it
is ordered that Jerrold M. Ladar, Esquire, of San Francisco, California,
is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 83-1785. Air France, Petitioner v. Valerie Hermien Saks. The
motion of The Republic of France for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.

292
MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985
No. 83–2143. Tennessee, Petitioner v. Harvey J. Street. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that George
Stuart Hampton, Esquire, of Elizabethtown, Tennessee, is appointed
to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 84–28. Donald C. Brockett, Appellant v. Spokane Arcades, Inc.,

No. 84–267. William P. Clark, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Southern Oregon Citizens Against Toxic Sprays, Inc. The
motion of respondent for attorney's fees is denied.
No. 84–315. Leonard G. Leverson, Appellant v. William H. Conway,
Commissioner, Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles. The appellee
is directed to file a response to the petition for rehearing within thirty
days.
No. 84–320. National Farmers Union Insurance Companies and
Lodge Grass School District No. 27, Petitioners v. Crow Tribe of In-
dians, et al. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Clarence T. Belue, Esquire, of Hardin, Montana, is ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondents Leroy Sage and Flora
Not Afraid in this case. Justice White took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 84-634. Chevron U. S. A., Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Jay S.
Hammond, Governor of Alaska, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States. Jus-
tice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 84-5004. Truman Lewis Ball, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of the Solicitor General to permit Andrew J. Pincus, Esquire, to
present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 84-5266. Maxine Denise Wynne Chambers, Petitioner v. Ameri-
can Greetings Corporation. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari that does not comply with the order of this
Court entered October 9, 1984, is denied. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.

MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1985
293
No. 84-5424. Howard R. Herships, Petitioner v. Robert M. Rees, Su-
perintendent, D. V. I. The application for stay addressed to Justice
Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 84-5706. Jeannette M. Paleno, et vir, Appellants v. County of
Lake, et al. The motion of appellants for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. Appellants are allowed until January 28, 1985, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
statement as to jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of
this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. - (1983),
we would dismiss the appeal for want of jurisdiction and, treating the
papers whereon the appeal would be taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, we would deny certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 83–1911. Christopher L. Lowe, et al., Petitioners v. Securities
and Exchange Commission. Argued by Mr. Michael E. Schoeman for
the petitioners and by Mr. Solicitor General Rex E. Lee for the
respondent.
No. 83–2166. Philip Q. Zauderer, Appellant v. Office of Disciplinary
Counsel of the Supreme Court of Ohio. Argued by Mr. Alan B. Morri-
son for the appellant and by Mr. H. Bartow Farr, III, for the appellee.
No. 83-1944. Holly Jensen, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Frances J.
Quaring. Argued by Ms. Ruth Anne E. Galter for the petitioners and
by Mr. Thomas C. Lansworth for the respondent.

agement, Petitioner v. Allison E. Nutt, et al. Argued by Mr. Charles
A. Rothfeld for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special order of the
Court, and by Mr. Charles A. Hobbie for the respondents.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1985
321
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 83–1132. Park 'N Fly, Inc., Petitioner v. Dollar Park and Fly,
Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 83–1330. United States, Petitioner v. Thomas J. Hensley. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan.
No. 83–1153. Mills Music, Inc., Petitioner v. Marie Snyder and Ted
Snyder, Jr., etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion
by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and
Justice Blackmun join.
No. 83-832. Harold T. Paulsen, et ux., Petitioners v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the
Chief Justice joins. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 83-997. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Harold H.
Thurston, et al.; and
No. 83–1325. Air Line Pilots Association, International, Petitioner v.
Harold H. Thurston, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, re-
versed in part, and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Powell announced by the Chief Justice.

322
TUESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1985
No. 83–963. Board of License Commissioners of the Town of Tiver-
ton, Petitioner v. Louis H. Pastore, Jr., etc., et al. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The writ of certiorari is dis-
missed as moot. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 9, 1985
323
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 83-727. Lamar Alexander, Governor of the State of Tennessee,
et al., Petitioners v. Hershel Choate, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Marshall.
No. 83-1007. Tiffany Fine Arts, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. United
States, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Marshall.
No. 83–240. Lawrence County, et al., Appellants v. Lead-Deadwood
School District No. 40-1. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South
Dakota. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of South Dakota for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Stevens joins.
No. 83-1020. Ohio, Petitioner v. William Lee Kovacs, dba B & W
Enterprises, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 83–1266. United States, Petitioner v. Robert W. Boyle, Execu-
tor of the Estate of Myra W. Boyle, Deceased. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall, Justice Powell, and Justice O'Connor join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1985
325
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-581. Michael W. Lasky, Appellant v. John Van Lindt, et al.
Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York,
First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 84-632. Allan Wilk and Palos Verdes Shores Mobile Estates,
Ltd., Appellants v. California. Appeal from the Appellate Department,
Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-753. Olga Ogrod, Appellant v. Tomlinson Court Apartments.
Appeal from the Court of Common Pleas of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 84-5696. Randolph E. Neal, Jr., Appellant v. Alabama. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–5762. James C. Rawlinson, Appellant v. Merit Oil Company,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.

326
MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1985
No. 84-739. Severo Pasillas, Appellant v. Agricultural Labor Rela-
tions Board; and
No. 84-746. Maria Guadalupe Navarro, Appellant v. Agriculture
Labor Relations Board of California and United Farm Workers of
America, AFL-CIO. Appeals from the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District. The appeals are dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
No. 84-768. Allstate Insurance Company, et al., Appellants v. Rich-
ard Baksalary, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The motion of appellees for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens would affirm
the judgment. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion and this case.
No. 84-5060. Charles Wright, Appellant v. New Jersey. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83–1963. Barrett Toan, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Lucinda Cun-
ningham, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of respondent Lu-
cinda Cunningham for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of the Deficit Reduction
Act of 1984, Pub. L. No. 98-369. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 84-681. Prudential Federal Savings and Loan Association, Peti-
tioner v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Trans World
Airlines, Inc. v. Thurston, 469 U. S. (1985). Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-

MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1985
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
327
No. —
In the Matter of Application of Stanley Charles Shapiro for
Readmission to the Bar of this Court. The application of Stanley
Charles Shapiro for readmission to the Bar of this Court is denied. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D-449. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ralph Hochstein. Disbar-
ment order entered. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this order.
No. D-451. In the Matter of Disbarment of Rafford Eugene Jones.
Disbarment order entered. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this order.
No. D-471. In the Matter of Disbarment of Cletus H. Brault, Jr. It is
ordered that Cletus H. Brault, Jr., of Crown Point, Indiana, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 83-1368. Northwest Wholesale Stationers, Inc., Petitioner v.
Pacific Stationery and Printing Co. The motion of Indian Head Inc. for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 83-1569. Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Petitioner v. Soler
Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc.; and
No. 83–1733. Soler Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc., Petitioner v. Mitsubishi
Motors Corporation. The motion of American Arbitration Association
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided
argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-231. Alvin D. Hooper and Mary N. Hooper, Appellants v.
Bernalillo County Assessor. The motion of American Legion, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84–325. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Appellant v.
Commonwealth of Massachusetts; and
No. 84–356. Travelers Insurance Company, Appellant v. Common-
wealth of Massachusetts. The motion of American Chiropractic Associ-
ation for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae in
No. 84-325, for divided argument and for additional time for oral argu-
ment is denied. The motion of appellants for divided argument is

328
MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1985
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.
No. 84–468. City of Cleburne, Texas, et al., Petitioners v. Cleburne
Living Center, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument
and for additional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of The
Federation of Greater Baton Rouge Civic Associations Inc. for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument
and for additional time for oral argument is denied. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-761. Data General Corporation, Petitioner v. Digidyne Cor-
poration, et al. The motion of Control Data Corp. for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Mercedes-Benz of North
America for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion
of Computer Automation, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-780. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Appellants v. Stephen J. Roy, et al. The motion of
appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-782. South Carolina, et al., Petitioners v. Catawba Indian
Tribe of South Carolina. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 84-1074. Lowell M. Stroom, Petitioner v. James E. Carter, etc.,
et al. The application for an injunction addressed to the Chief Justice
and referred to the Court is denied. The motion of petitioner to expe-
dite consideration of the petition for writ of certiorari is denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this application
and motion.
No. 84-5873. Melvin Davis and Maria T. Davis, Petitioners v. United
States Government, et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed until Febru-
ary 4, 1985, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule
45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of
this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. (1983),
we would deny the petition for writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

decision of these petitions.

petition. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted
for oral argument. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these petitions.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
OPINION
No. 83-712. New Jersey, Petitioner v. T. L. O. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of New Jersey for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell with whom Justice O'Con-
nor joins. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part
with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Marshall joins and
with whom Justice Brennan joins as to Part I.

MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1985
353
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and Justice
O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-807. Boehringer Mannheim Diagnostics, Inc., fka Hycel, Inc.,
Appellant v. Pan American World Airways, Inc. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-846. William Randolph Klein, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal
from the Circuit Court of Twelfth Judicial Circuit of Florida, Sarasota
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 84-5481. Saul Vega, Appellant v. New York. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 84-5875. Randolph E. Neal, Jr., Appellant v. American Tele-
phone and Telegraph Co., etc.; and Randolph E. Neal, Jr., Appellant v.
City of Huntsville, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-485. Eugene J. Carella, Applicant v. Billy M. Cooper and Gen-
eral Electric Company, Inc., et al. The application to recall and stay the
mandate addressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is de-
nied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.

354
MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1985
No. D-458. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph J. Rey, Sr. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-472. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan Manning Miller. It is
ordered that Alan Manning Miller, of Garden City, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-1935. Tony and Susan Alamo Foundation, et al., Petitioners
v. Raymond J. Donovan, Secretary of Labor. The motion of American
Civil Liberties Union for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 83-1961. Landreth Timber Company, Petitioner v. Ivan K.
Landreth, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is de-
nied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 84-165. W. George Gould, Petitioner v. Max A. Ruefenacht, et
al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 83–2143. Tennessee, Petitioner v. Harvey J. Street. The motion
of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for divided argument is granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-28. Donald C. Brockett, Appellant v. Spokane Arcades, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 84–143. Kenneth Eikenberry, Attorney General of Washington,
et al., Appellants v. J-R Distributors, Inc., et al. The motion of Ameri-
can Booksellers Association, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 84–465. Lee Roy Black, Director, Missouri Department of Cor-
rections and Human Resources and Dick D. Moore, Chairman, Missouri
Board of Probation and Parole, Petitioners v. Nicholas J. Romano. The
motion of the Attorney General of Missouri to permit David C. Mason,
Esquire, of Jefferson City, Missouri, to argue pro hac vice is granted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1985
355
No. 84-718. Robert L. Mendenhall, Petitioner v. United States, et al.
The motion of Wayne Winters, Editor and Publisher of Western Pros-
pector and Miner, for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 84-5343. Ruel Hux, Jr., Petitioner v. A. I. Murphy, Warden, et
al. The motion of petitioner to consolidate this case with No. 83–1590,
Francis v. Franklin, is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-755. United States, Petitioner v. Rosa Elvira Montoya de
Hernandez. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.
No. 84-823. United States, Petitioner v. John Doe No. 462. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.
No. 84-861. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Interna-
tional Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 83-1038. Helen Doring, Executrix of the Estate of Jessie E.
Kerber, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 83-1647. Lindy Pen Company, Inc., and Blackfeet Plastics, Inc.,
Petitioners v. Bic Pen Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 83-1864. Richard Thornburgh, Governor of Pennsylvania, et al.,
Petitioners v. Martin Nelson, Paula Buntele, and Thomas Mobley. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 84-5802. In Re David Ely, Petitioner. Petition for writ of manda-
mus is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 83-6775. Lillian Thompson, Petitioner v. Louisiana;
No. 84-5579. Harvey Johnpoll, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 84-5647. John R. Mazak, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 84-5715. Alphonso D'Arco, Petitioner v. United States. The peti-
tions for rehearing are denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of these petitions.
No. 84-5483. Hugh McIntosh, Petitioner v. United States, et al. The
motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing and all other relief is
denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.

No. 83-1625. United States, Petitioner v. Lyle Gerald Johns, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 83-1622. Elizabeth Brandon, et al., Petitioners v. John D. Holt,
etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1985
373
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by the Chief Justice
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 83-1427. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. Johnny Paul Witt. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall
joins.
No. 83-1378. Ralph W. Evitts, Superintendent, Blackburn Correc-
tional Complex and David L. Armstrong, Attorney General, Petition-
ers v. Keith E. Lucey. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice joins.
The Chief Justice said:
"The Court will now rise to attend the inauguration of the President
and Vice President of the United States.”
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 19, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 29, 1985
375
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-584. James David Raulerson, Applicant v. Louis L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of the sentence of death scheduled for
Wednesday, January 30, 1985, presented to Justice Rehnquist and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1985
377
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-603. Louis L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, et al., Applicants v. Carl Ray Songer. The Application
to vacate the stay of execution of the sentence of death entered by
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit presented
to Justice Rehnquist and by him referred to the Court is denied. Jus-
tice Rehnquist dissents. The Chief Justice, Justice Powell and Jus-
tice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1985
379
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-597. Willie Lawrence Celestine, Applicant v. Frank Black-
burn, Warden, Louisiana State Penitentiary. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Saturday, February 9,
1985, presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
granted pending the timely filing and disposition by this Court of a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari
be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event the petition
for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the
sending down of the judgment of this Court. Justice White, Justice
Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor would deny the application. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
381
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-827. John Westhafer, Judge, Circuit Court of Decatur
County, Indiana, et al., Appellants v. Worrell Newspapers of Indiana,
Inc., etc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Rehnquist would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-833. Bean Dredging Corporation, Appellant v. Alabama. Ap-
peal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-918. Union Central Life Insurance Company, Appellant v. Jo-
anne Limbach, Tax Commissioner of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 84-952. Julius M. Gerzof, Appellant v. Grievance Committee for
the Tenth Judicial District. Appeal from the Appellate Division, Su-
preme Court of New York, Second Judicial Department. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–1040. Mary Williams Cazalas, Dative Testamentary Execu-
trix of the Succession of Albert Joseph Cazalas, Appellant v. Julia C.
Griot, Dative Testamentary Executrix, etc. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-911. Erich Koker and Beatrice E. Koker, Appellants v. Noel
B. Sage and Winetta Sage. Appeal from the Superior Court of Wash-
ington, King County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

382
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-937. Wesley K. Bell, etc., Appellant v. New Jersey, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 84-5860. Bernie J. E. Dingle, Appellant v. Calvin D. Simpkins,
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-5974. Randolph E. Neal, Jr., Appellant v. Alabama, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 84-1027. Berman & Sons, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Lana J.
Scofield and A. Larry Berren, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial
Court of Massachusetts. The motion of appellees for award of damages
and double costs is denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 84-1031. Communications Satellite Corporation, Appellant v.
Franchise Tax Board. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction
and set the case for oral argument. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-5610. Lenny K. Beck, Appellant v. Kansas. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Kansas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
383
No. 83-1613. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. Willie Jasper Darden. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Wainwright v. Witt, 469 U.S. (1985). Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 84-578. Avtex Fibers, Inc., Petitioner v. Robert L. McDowell.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Thurston, 469 U.S. (1985). Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-557. Gary R. Eitel, Applicant v. Charles R. Baldwin. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Powell and referred to the
Court is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this application.
No. D-463. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry W. Hopt. Disbar-
ment order entered. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this order.
No. D-466. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bobby L. Hill. Disbar-
ment order entered. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this order.
No. D-473. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert White Hutchins.
It is ordered that Robert White Hutchins, of Columbia, North Carolina,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D-474. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Thomas Kozel. It
is ordered that William Thomas Kozel, of San Luis Obispo, California,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he

384
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D-475. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bert Padell. It is ordered
that Bert Padell, of New York, New York, be suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within forty
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this order.
No. D-476. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald Paul Whittington.
It is ordered that Ronald Paul Whittington, of Destrehan, Louisiana, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D-477. In the Matter of Disbarment of John B. Kennedy. It is
ordered that John B. Kennedy, of Wilmington, Delaware, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.

French Smith, Attorney General of the United States. The motion for
leave to file a bill of complaint is denied. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.

Petitioners v. United States. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a
supplemental brief after argument is granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 83–1919. City of Oklahoma City, Petitioner v. Rose Marie Tuttle,
etc. The motion of respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief after
argument is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.

homa, Appellant v. National Gay Task Force. The motion of appellee
for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument is granted. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

et al. The renewed motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
385
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of

No. 84–312. Donald J. Devine, Director, Office of Personnel Manage-
ment, Petitioner v. NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund,
Inc., et al. The motion of respondents to file appendix that does not
comply with the Rules of the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens would grant this motion. Justice Marshall and Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-320. National Farmers Union Insurance Companies and
Lodge Grass School District No. 27, Petitioners v. Crow Tribe of In-
dians, et al. The motion of Salt River Project Agricultural Improve-
ment and Power District, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
The motion of Montana for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for divided argument is granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-433. School Committee of the Town of Burlington, Massachu-
setts, et al., Petitioners v. Department of Education of the Common-
wealth of Massachusetts, et al. The motion of respondents for divided
argument is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 84–468. City of Cleburne, Texas, et al., Petitioners v. Cleburne
Living Center, et al. The motion of Texas, et al. for leave to participate
in oral argument as amici curiae, for divided argument and for addi-
tional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of Disabled Peoples'
International, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
The motion of American Association on Mental Deficiency, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of National
Conference of Catholic Charities, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. The motion of Disability Rights Education and De-
fense Fund for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of American Civil Liberties Union Foundation, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-510. Aspen Skiing Company, Petitioner v. Aspen Highlands
Skiing Corporation. The motion of American Airlines, Inc. for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
No. 84-648. Sedima, S. P. R. L., Petitioner v. Imrex Company, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 84-822. American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago,
et al., Petitioners v. Haroco, Inc., et al. The application of the Attorney

in excess of the page limitation presented to Justice Marshall and by

consideration or decision of this application.
No. 84-755. United States, Petitioner v. Rosa Elvira Montoya de
Hernandez. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Peter M. Horstman, Esquire, of Los Angeles, California,
is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84–951. Gulf Coast Cable Television Co., Petitioner v. Affiliated
Capital Corp. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 84-1222. Farrell Kahn, Petitioner v. Alexander Grant & Com-
pany. The motion of petitioner to expedite consideration of the petition
for a writ of certiorari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84–1226. Robert E. Badham, et al., Petitioners v. Secretary of
State of California, et al. The motion of petitioners to expedite consid-
eration of the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-1244. Susan J. Davis, et al., Appellants v. Irwin C.
Bandemer, et al. The motion of appellants to expedite consideration of
the appeal is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 84-5909. Tim Lee Adams, Petitioner v. Thomas Fulcomer, Su-
perintendent, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 12, 1985,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S.
(1983), we would deny the petition for writ of certiorari without reach-

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
387
ing the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-5918. Clark W. Rowland, Petitioner v. Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 12, 1985,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
-
No. 84-6044. Roy Anderson Day, Petitioner v. James DeAnda,
Judge, et al. The motion of petitioner to expedite consideration of the
petition for writ of certiorari or in the alternative issue a temporary
restraining order is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-435. Robert Russell, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

States Marshals Service, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

Lockett, Petitioners v. David Saxner and Alfred Cain, Jr. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

Inc., et al. The motion of National Wildlife Federation, et al. for leave
to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.

motion and this petition.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
No. 84-744. United States, Petitioner v. James C. Lane and Dennis
R. Lane; and
No. 84-963. James C. Lane and Dennis R. Lane, Petitioners v.
United States. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. The cases are consoli-
dated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 84–773. Michael Bender, et al., Petitioners v. Williamsport Area
School District, et al. The motion of National Association of Secondary
School Principals for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion and this petition.
No. 84-786. Maine, Petitioner v. Perley Moulton, Jr. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine granted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and this petition.
No. 84-1023. United States, Petitioner v. Fernando Rojas-
Contreras. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.
No. 84-801. Midlantic National Bank, Petitioner v. New Jersey De-
partment of Environmental Protection; and
No. 84-805. Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Re-
sources Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. City of New York, et al.;
and Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Resources
Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. New Jersey Department of Envi-
ronmental Protection. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted. The cases are
consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
petitions.
No. 84-5872. Roy E. Daniels, Petitioner v. Andrew Williams. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this petition.

OPINIONS
No. 35, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. States of
Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York,
New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South
Carolina, Georgia and Florida (Rhode Island and New York Boundary
case). Exceptions of United States, Rhode Island and New York over-
ruled. Recommendation of the Special Master adopted and Report con-
firmed. Parties to submit appropriate proposed decree to the Special
Master for Court's consideration. Each party to bear its own costs. Ac-
tual expenses of the Special Master to be borne half by the United
States and half by Rhode Island and New York. The Court retains ju-

432
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985
risdiction to entertain such further proceedings, enter such orders, and
issue such writs as from time to time may be deemed necessary or ad-
visable to effectuate and supplement the decree and the rights of the
respective parties. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 82-1913. Joe G. Garcia, Appellant v. San Antonio Metropolitan
Transit Authority, et al.; and
No. 82-1951. Raymond J. Donovan, Secretary of Labor, Appellant v.
San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority, et al. Appeals from the
United States District Court for the Western District of Texas. Judg-
ment reversed and cases remanded to the District Court for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor
with whom Justice Powell and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 83-1416. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Action
Automotive, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor
join.

OPINIONS
No. 82-5920. Kevin Michael Shea, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 83-1476. United States, Petitioner v. Mary Dann and Carrie
Dann. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
No. 83–469. United States, Petitioner v. Billy G. Young. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and
dissenting in part with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1985
437
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-641. Howard Mattheson, Applicant v. C. Paul Phelps, Secre-
tary, Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections. The
application for stay of execution of the sentence of death scheduled
for Monday, February 25, 1985, presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court is granted pending the timely filing and dis-
position by this Court of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should the
petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of
this Court. Justice White and Justice Rehnquist would deny the appli-
cation. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1985
439
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
"
No. 84-1079. Bethune Plaza, Incorporated, Appellant v. E. Allen
Bernardi, Director of Labor of Illinois. Appeal from the Appellate
Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–1092. Aaron Mark Zimmerman, Appellant v. Robert Abrams,
Attorney General of New York, et al. Appeal from the Appellate Divi-
sion, Supreme Court of New York, Fourth Judicial Department. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 84-5912. Jimmy Calloway, Appellant v. Alabama. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–5396. Bryan Jennings, Petitioner v. Florida. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Shea v. Louisiana, 470 U. S. (1985) and Smith v. Illinois,
469 U. S. (1984). Justice Rehnquist dissents. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-608. Eugene J. Carella and Paula E. Pfister, Applicants v.
Municipal Court of Los Angeles, et al. The application for stay ad-

440
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1985
dressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. D-459. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth M. Stachurski.
Disbarment order entered.

barment order entered.

No. 83-1961. Landreth Timber Company, Petitioner v. Ivan K.
Landreth, et al. The motion of Advance Ross Corporation for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-4. Williamson County Regional Planning Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City. The motion of petitioner
for leave to file reply brief, out-of-time, is granted. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84–468. City of Cleburne, Texas, et al., Petitioners v. Cleburne
Living Center, et al. The motion of Association for Retarded Citizens of
the United States, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of The National Association for Rights Protection
and Advocacy, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.
No. 84-861. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Inter-
national Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO, et al. The motion of
respondents New York Shipping Association, Inc., et al. for divided
argument is granted. The motion of the Solicitor General for divided
argument is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these motions.
No. 84-978. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Robert Hunt,
Administrator of New Jersey Spill Compensation Fund, et al. The So-
licitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views
of the United States. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this order.
No. 84-1282. In Re Victor E. Murgo, Applicant. The application for
stay addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the Court is denied.

Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.

Warden, et al. The orders entered May 21, 1984, suspending the effect
of the order denying the petition for writ of certiorari and staying
execution of sentence of death are vacated. The petition for rehearing
is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these orders.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 4, 1985, until
Monday, March 18, 1985.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State
Judith A. Miller
Washington, DC
Steven A. Kaufman
Boston, MA
Movant
Mr. Justice Potter
Stewart
Addison Lane
McGovern
OPINIONS
No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of
Louisiana, et al. (Alabama and Mississippi Boundary case). Exception
of the United States to the ruling by the Special Master that Mississippi
Sound is historic inland waters is overruled. Exceptions of Alabama and
Mississippi and remaining Exceptions of the United States are not
ruled upon. Recommendations and Report of the Special Master
adopted and confirmed to the extent they are consistent with the opin-
ion. Parties are to submit an appropriate proposed decree to the Special
Master for the Court's consideration. Each party is to bear its own
costs. Actual expenses of the Special Master to be borne half by the
United States and half by Alabama and Mississippi. Court retains juris-
diction to entertain such further proceedings, enter such orders, and
issue such writs as from time to time may be deemed necessary or
advisable to effectuate and supplement the decree and the rights of the
respective parties. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 83-5424. Glen Burton Ake, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.

458
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1985
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 84-76. Nell Hunter, et al., etc., Appellants v. Victor Underwood
and Carmen Edwards, etc. Argued by Mr. James S. Ward for the ap-
pellants and by Mr. Wilson Edward Still, Jr., for the appellees.
No. 84-127. Richardson-Merrell, Inc., Petitioner v. Anne Elisabeth
Koller, etc., et al. Argued by Mr. Lawrence E. Walsh for the petitioner
and by Mr. Michael H. Gottesman for the respondents.
No. 84-325. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Appellant v.
Commonwealth of Massachusetts; and
No. 84-356. Travelers Insurance Company, Appellant v. Common-
wealth of Massachusetts. Argued by Mr. Jay Greenfield for the appel-
lant in No. 84-325, by Mr. Addison Lane McGovern for the appellant in
No. 84-356, and by Ms. Sally A. Kelly for the appellee.
No. 84-16. Kenneth Cory, Leo T. McCarthy and Jesse R. Huff,
Appellants v. Western Oil and Gas Association, et al. Argued by
Mr. Dennis Eagan for the appellants and by Mr. Philip K. Verleger for
the appellees.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

459
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 83-1097. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Sandra Turner, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun.
No. 83–1013. Chemical Manufacturers Association, et al., Petitioners
v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 83–1373. United States Environmental Protection Agency, Peti-
tioner v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join, and with whom Justice
O'Connor joins as to Parts I, II, and III. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor.
No. 83-1015. National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People, etc., et al., Appellants v. Hampton County Election Commis-
sion, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of South Carolina. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Justice Powell
and Justice Rehnquist concur in the judgment.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1985
461
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
“Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 84-914. St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Robert Wayne Dickerson. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court
of Appeals of Missouri, Eastern District. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting statement by Justice
Marshall. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–1214. Ransom Charles, Appellant v. Kentucky. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 84-6049. James W. Raphael-Johnson, Appellant v. District of
Columbia. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-613. United States, Petitioner v. Thomas O. Robinson, Jr. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in
light of United States v. Young, 470 U. S. (1985). Justice Brennan
would deny certiorari. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
