MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1985
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-642. Arletta Faye Brownlee, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred
to the Court is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this application.
No. D-479. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Goffen. It is
ordered that William Goffen, of Brooklyn, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-480. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren J. Black. It is
ordered that Warren J. Black, of New City, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-481. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene Gold. It is
ordered that Eugene Gold, of Brooklyn, New York, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84–261. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Petitioner v.
Gary Weintraub, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit
Bruce N. Kuhlik, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 84-363. Northeast Bancorp, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Board of
Governors of the Federal Reserve System, et al. The motion of The
David F. Bolger Revocable Trust for leave to file a brief as amicus cu-
riae is granted. The motion of The Bank of New York Company, Inc.
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of New
York State Bankers Association for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted. The motion of Alphonse M. D'Amato, et al. for leave
to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-433. School Committee of the Town of Burlington, Massachu-
setts, et al., Petitioners v. Department of Education of the Common-
wealth of Massachusetts, et al. The motion of The Developmental Dis-
abilities Law Center, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.

this order.

CERTIORARI GRANTED

Hillery, Jr. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.

petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama is granted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and this petition.

tendent, Ohio Reformatory for Women. Motion of petitioner for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit is
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion and this petition.

Texas, et al.;

County of Orange; and
No. 84-5891. William M. Slater, Petitioner v. United States. The
petitions for rehearing are denied. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of these petitions.

OPINIONS
No. 83-773. Oregon, Petitioner v. Michael James Elstad. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Oregon. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 83–1452. R. Anthony Marrese and Michael R. Treister, Petition-
ers v. American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the
judgment. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 83-1785. Air France, Petitioner v. Valerie Hermien Saks. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 83-1708. Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., Petitioner v. A. Lamar
Byrd. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed insofar as it upheld the District
Court's denial of the motion to compel arbitration and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion
by Justice White.
No. 83-1065. County of Oneida, New York, et al., Petitioners v.
Oneida Indian Nation of New York State, etc., et al.; and
No. 83–1240. New York, Petitioner v. Oneida Indian Nation of New
York State, etc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed with respect to
the finding of liability under federal law, and reversed with respect to
the exercise of ancillary jurisdiction over the counties' cross-claim for

476
MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1985
indemnification and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Powell announced by the Chief Justice. Justice Stevens concurs
in the judgment with respect to No. 83-1240. Opinion by Justice Bren-
nan concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Mar-
shall joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens dissenting in No. 83–1065 with
whom the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 83-1466. Supreme Court of New Hampshire, Appellant v. Kath-
ryn A. Piper. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell announced
by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the result.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.

Adjourned until Monday, March 18, 1985 at 10 o'clock.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 84-5555. Larry Gene Heath, Petitioner v. Alabama. The order of
March 4, 1985 granting the petition for writ of certiorari is amended
to read as follows: "The motion of the petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted limited to Question II. In addition, the parties are requested to
address the following questions: What is the applicability, if any, of the
dual sovereignty doctrine to successive prosecutions by two different
states?" " Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion and this petition.
"

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 5, 1985
479
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-6325. Johnny Paul Witt, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The application
for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice
Rehnquist and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with
whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice Stevens would grant the applica-
tion for stay. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this application and this petition.
REHEARING DENIED
No. 84-6325. Johnny Paul Witt, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The petition for
rehearing of the denial of certiorari and of the order denying the stay of
execution of the sentence of death is denied. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.

!

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1985
481
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 84-690. United States, Petitioner v. Robert Paul Gagnon, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondents to supplement the
record is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall joins. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion and this petition.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–1168. Jerome J. Nash, Appellant v. City of Santa Monica,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-6081. James E. Johnson, Appellant v. New Jersey. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-6227. Paul Richard Manko, Appellant v. United States. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–1089. Nick N. Novicky, Petitioner v. Syntex Ophthalmics,
Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court

482
MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1985
of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Marrese v. American Academy of Orthopaedic
Surgeons, 470 U.S. (1985). Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
-

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Life for God's Stray Animals, Inc., Gerald Fields and Ann
P. Fields, Petitioners v. New North Rockdale County Homeowners As-
sociation, Inc., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for
writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. D-478. In the Matter of Disbarment of Anna Cotton Hailey. It is
ordered that Anna Cotton Hailey, of Elwood, Indiana, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring her to show cause why she should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D-482. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Miles Brunwin.
It is ordered that Thomas Miles Brunwin, of Arcadia, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D-483. In the Matter of Disbarment of Clifford Jackson Bond,
III. It is ordered that Clifford Jackson Bond, III, of Winston-Salem,
North Carolina, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this order.
No. 83-1925. Hillsborough County, Florida, et al., Appellants v.
Automated Medical Laboratories, Inc. The motion of American Blood
Resources Association for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for divided argument is granted. The motion of the Solic-
itor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae
and for divided argument is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions.

Governors of the Federal Reserve System, et al. The motion of Frank

no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.

No. 84-6158. Louis T. Ferrara, Petitioner v. Becton, Dickinson &
Co., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until April 8, 1985, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.

500
MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1985
opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice

No. 84-6316. Jesse de la Rosa, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to
our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant
the application for stay, the petition for writ of certiorari and vacate the
death sentence in this case. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this application and this petition.
COMMON LAW CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-5543. In Re Orlando H. Johnson, Jr., Petitioner. The petition
for writ of common law certiorari denied. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 84-1282. In Re Victor E. Murgo, Petitioner. The petition for a
writ of mandamus and/or prohibition is denied. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 84-1312. In Re Patricia S. Kaczmarek, Petitioner. The petition
for writ of prohibition is denied. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.

OPINIONS
No. 83-1032. Federal Election Commission, Appellant v. National
Conservative Political Action Committee, et al.; and
No. 83–1122. Democratic Party of the United States and Democratic
National Committee, Appellants v. National Conservative Political

508
MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1985
Action Committee and Fund for a Conservative Majority. Appeals from
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylva-
nia. Judgment affirmed as to the constitutionality of 26 U. S. C.
9012(f), reversed on the issue of the Democrats' standing, and cases
remanded to the United States District Court for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehn-
quist. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in
part. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall join as to Part I. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall.
No. 83–1492. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, Appellant v.
Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, et al.; and
No. 83–1633. Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company,
et al., Appellants v. National Railroad Passenger Corporation. Appeals
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.
No. 83-728. Herb's Welding, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Robert H.
Gray, Jr., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun, and
Justice O'Connor join.

OPINIONS
No. 83-2064. William J. Bennett, Secretary of Education, Petitioner
v. New Jersey. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Powell
took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-1798. William J. Bennett, Secretary of Education, Petitioner
v. Kentucky Department of Education. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Justice White and Justice Blackmun join only in Parts I, II,
IV, and V of this opinion. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of
this petition.
No. 83-1620. First National Bank of Atlanta, etc., Appellant v.
Bartow County Board of Tax Assessors, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun.
No. 83-1362. Cleveland Board of Education, Petitioner v. James
Loudermill, et al.;
No. 83-1363. Parma Board of Education, Petitioner v. Richard Don-
nelly, et al.; and

Education, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice
Marshall concurring in Part II and concurring in the judgment. Opinion
by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Rehnquist.

No. A-705. John Young, Applicant v. Ralph Kemp, Warden. The
application for stay of execution of the sentence of death scheduled for

No. 83-1878. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Larry Leon Chaney, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment.
No. 83-6766. Joe Hayes, Petitioner v. Florida. On writ of certiorari
to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the District Court of Appeal for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice White. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Blackmun concurs in the
judgment. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-5954. Wayne Lindahl, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel Man-
agement. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice White with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1985
515
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83–1868. John E. White, Appellant v. Dougherty County Board
of Education, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Middle District of Georgia. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 84-18. Florence Talamini, Administratrix of Estate of John A.
Talamini, Appellant v. Allstate Insurance Company. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
Concurring opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Rehnquist
and Justice O'Connor join. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens, with
whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
Justice White, believing that there is no final judgment to review,
would dismiss for want of jurisdiction. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–337. Owen W. Crumpacker, Appellant v. Indiana Supreme
Court Disciplinary Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Concurring opinion by The Chief Justice. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-1082. Oppenheimer & Co., Inc., Appellant v. Marcia A.
Young. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for
further consideration in light of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. v. Byrd,
470 U. S. (1985). Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction
and set the case for oral argument. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

516
MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1985
No. 84–1155. Westinghouse Electric Company, Appellant v. John K.
King, Commissioner of Revenue of Tennessee. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-1303. Caddo Parish School Board, Appellant v. Margaret
Smith Bryan, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana,
Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 84–6164. William Rider, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal from the
District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–1176. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., Ap-
pellant v. Public Service Commission of New York, et al. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of New York. The motion of Edison Electric Insti-
tute for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The request of
counsel for appellant to delete Brooklyn Union Gas Company as a party
to these proceedings is denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with
whom Justice Blackmun joins. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 84–1293. Harry Leroy Kelley, Appellant v. Texas Real Estate
Commission. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
CERTIORARI -SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-2101. Howard A. Daniel, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel
Management. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further
consideration in light of Lindahl v. Office of Personnel Management,
470 U. S. (1985). Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
-

MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1985
517
No. 83-6034. Sally R. Swanson, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel
Management, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
for further consideration in light of Lindahl v. Office of Personnel
Management, 470 U. S. (1985). Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
-
No. 83-6093. Charles M. Gates, Petitioner v. U. S. Postal Service.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further consideration in
light of Lindahl v. Office of Personnel Management, 470 U. S.
(1985). Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 83-6440. Clinton Smith, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel Man-
agement. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Lindahl v. Office of Personnel Management, 470
U. S. (1985). Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
-
No. 83-7032. Jerome Bowden, Petitioner v. Robert Francis, War-
den. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Ake v. Oklahoma, 470 U. S. (1985). Dis-
senting opinion by Justice O'Connor, with whom Justice White and
Justice Rehnquist join. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
-
No. 84-244. Florida, Petitioner v. Jeffrey Nease, etc. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth

518
MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1985
District. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, Fourth District, for further consideration in light of Florida v.
Rodriguez, 469 U. S. (1984). Justice Powell took no part in the
-
consideration or decision of this case.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Thomas Lynn, Petitioner v. Illinois. The motion to direct
the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari without the affidavit of
indigency executed by petitioner is denied. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. A-695. Michael Drape, Applicant v. United States. The applica-
tion to recall and stay pending timely filing of a petition for writ
of certiorari addressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is
denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.

Disbarment order entered.

DiAngelus. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-469. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren Douglas Uter-
mahlen. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-484. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Edward Wollrab.
It is ordered that James Edward Wollrab, of St. Louis, Missouri, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-485. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alex Gerhart Logan, III.
It is ordered that Alex Gerhart Logan, III, of Tustin, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Leonard Adolph Delk, of San Diego, California, be

APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 84–1044. Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Appellant v. Public
Utilities Commission of California, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of California. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 84-1076. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Appellant
v. State Oil and Gas Board of Mississippi and Coastal Exploration, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. In this case proba-
ble jurisdiction is noted. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 84–1244. Susan J. Davis, et al., Appellants v. Irwin C.
Bandemer, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Indiana. The motion of appellees to strike the brief
of Members of the California Democratic Congressional Delegation as
amicus curiae is denied. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and this case.

No. 84–695. Gwendolyn L. King, etc., Appellant v. United States
District Court for the Central District of California, et al. (Integrity
Home Loan Co., Inc., et al., Real Parties in Interest);
No. 84-5783. James E. Billiot, Petitioner v. Mississippi; and
No. 84-5901. Le'rnard H. J. Chaney, Petitioner v. National Railroad
Passenger Corporation. The petitions for rehearing are denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 1, 1985, until Mon-
day, April 15, 1985.

Sidney S. Wolchok
Mr. Solicitor General Rex E. Lee said:
"Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I have the honor to
present to the Court the seventy-fifth Attorney General of the United
States, the Honorable Edwin Meese, III."
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, on behalf of the Court I welcome you as the
chief law officer of the government and as an officer of this Court. We
welcome you to the performance of the very important duties which will
rest on you by virtue of your office. Your commission as Attorney Gen-
eral of the United States will be placed in the records of the Court. We
wish you well in your new office."

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 83-1935. Tony and Susan Alamo Foundation, et al., Petitioners
v. Secretary of Labor. Argued by Mr. Roy R. Gean, Jr., for the peti-
tioners and by Mr. Charles Fried for the respondent.
No. 84-438. Superintendent, Massachusetts Correctional Institution,
Walpole, Petitioner v. Gerald Hill and Joseph Crawford. Argued by
Ms. Barbara A. H. Smith for the petitioner and by Ms. Jamie Ann
Sabino for the respondents.
No. 84-5240. Marie Lucie Jean, et al., Petitioners v. Alan Nelson,
Commissioner, Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al. Argued
by Mr. Ira Jay Kurzban for the petitioners and by Mr. Solicitor General
Rex E. Lee for the respondents.
No. 84-351. Atascardero State Hospital and California Department
of Mental Health, Petitioners v. Douglas James Scanlon. Argued by
Mr. James E. Ryan for the petitioners and by Ms. Marilyn Holle for the
respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 26, 1985
535
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 83–1274. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, et al., Appel-
lants v. W. G. Ward, Jr., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Alabama. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Alabama for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 84-5004. Truman Lewis Ball, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
with instructions to have the United States District Court for the West-
ern District of Virginia exercise its discretion to vacate one of the
convictions. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Stevens
concurring in the judgment. Justice Marshall concurs in the judgment.
Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-2030. Board of Education of the City of Oklahoma City, Okla-
homa, Appellant v. National Gay Task Force. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an
equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Jus-
tice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-6663. Charles Fugate, Petitioner v. New Mexico. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Mexico. Judgment affirmed by
an equally divided divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the
Chief Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 27, 1985
537
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 82-1832. Town of Hallie, et al., Petitioners v. City of Eau Claire.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell.
No. 82-1922. Southern Motor Carriers Rate Conference, Inc., et al.,
Petitioners v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice White joins.
No. 83–1035. Tennessee, Appellant v. Cleamtee Garner, etc., et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit;
and
No. 83–1070. Memphis Police Department, et al., Petitioners v.
Cleamtee Garner, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and cases
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief Justice and Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 84–16. Kenneth Cory, Leo T. McCarthy and Jesse R. Huff,
Appellants v. Western Oil and Gas Association, et al. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by
the Chief Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 84-249. Roger L. Spencer, et ux., Petitioners v. South Carolina
Tax Commission, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
South Carolina. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opin-
ion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Justice Powell took no
part in the decision of this case.
No. 84-277. Board of Trustees of the Village of Scarsdale, et al.,
Petitioners v. Kathleen S. McCreary, et al. On writ of certiorari to

538
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 27, 1985
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by
the Chief Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.

יז

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 1, 1985
539
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 84-436. Bill Honig, Superintendent of Public Instruction of Cali-
fornia, et al., Petitioners v. Students of The California School for the
Blind, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with instructions to remand the
case to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
California for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens join. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 84–724. Texas A & M University, et al., Appellants v. Gay Stu-
dent Services, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. The motion of appellants to disqualify counsel for
appellees and to strike appellees' motion to dismiss or affirm is denied.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-2034. United States Department of Justice, Petitioner v.
Evelyn Falkowski. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Heckler v.
Chaney, 470 U. S. ——— (1985).

540
MONDAY, APRIL 1, 1985
No. 83-2035. United States, Petitioner v. Mark Arden Schmucker.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Wayte v. United States, 470 U. S. - (1985).
No. 84-823. United States, Petitioner v. John Doe No. 462. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit with instructions to dis-
miss the cause as moot.
No. 84-5035. Larry Bernard Spikes, Petitioner v. Indiana. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Indiana for further consideration in
light of Hayes v. Florida, 470 U. S. (1985).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-453. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gary Zane Nothstein.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-467. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Allen McGlas-
son, Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. 102, Original. State of Indiana, Plaintiff v. United States of
America, United States House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill,
Jr., Benjamin J. Guthrie, Jack Russ and James T. Malloy. The motion
of plaintiff to expedite consideration of the motion for leave to file a bill
of complaint is denied.
No. 84-468. City of Cleburne, Texas, et al., Petitioners v. Cleburne
Living Center, et al. This case is restored to the calendar for re-
argument. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision.
of this order.
No. 84-679. Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, Incorporated, Peti-
tioner v. Carl F. Berner, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to
permit Bruce N. Kuhlik, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac
vice is granted. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 84-806. Buckingham Corporation, Petitioner v. Odom Corpora-
tion, dba Arizona Distributing Company. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.

No. 84-836. Daniel Vasquez, Warden, Petitioner v. Booker T.

forma pauperis is granted.

of these petitions.

OPINIONS
No. 83–1750. United States, Petitioner v. James Rual Miller. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-

MONDAY, APRIL 1, 1985
555
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Marshall. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of
this case.
No. 83–1394. United States, et al., Appellants v. Madison D. Locke,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for District of
Nevada. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the District Court
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 83–2126. Oklahoma, Petitioner v. Timothy R. Castleberry and
Nicholas Raineri. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals
of Oklahoma. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Justice Powell took no part
in the decision of this case.
No. 84-5059. Patrick Ramirez, Petitioner v. Indiana. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Indiana. Judgment affirmed by
an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief
Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, April 15, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1985
557
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 84–501. Barry Mintzes, Warden, Petitioner v. Nealy Buchanon.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. The Court is advised that the respondent died in Ingham
County, Michigan, on December 7, 1984. The Court's order granting
the writ of certiorari, see
(1984), therefore is vacated,
and the petition for certiorari is dismissed. See Warden v. Palermo,
431 U.S. 911 (1977). Opinion per curiam. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
U.S.
-
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 84–1093. Troy L. Welch and Jay F. Welch, Appellants v. Clai-
borne County Beer Board, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Tennessee, Eastern Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Justice White and Justice Blackmun would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 84-1299. Ramiro Arango, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal from the
District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-1441. Roger J. Kay, Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Appeal from
the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-6425. Joe Kenneth White, Appellant v. R. Mark McGoff, Su-
perintendent, Fremont Correctional Facility. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

558
MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1985
No. 84-1329. Diane B. Crea, Appellant v. New York. Appeal from
the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, 9th & 10th Ju-
dicial Districts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 84-1346. Paul Heinrich, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction.
No. 84-6256. James Walton Mack, Jr., Appellant v. American Tele-
phone and Telegraph Company, Long Lines, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84-1382. Celia Stern, et al., Appellants v. Robert Weiss, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Blackmun
would note probable jurisdiction and give this case plenary con-
sideration.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Ireneusz Furman, Petitioner v. Commissioner of Internal
Revenue. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari that does not comply with Rule 33 is denied. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time is
denied.
No. . In the Matter of Admission of Selden B. Hale, III. On
application for admission to the Bar of this Court. The application for
admission to the Bar of this Court presented to Justice White and by
him referred to the Court is granted. Dissenting opinion by the Chief
Justice with whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. . In the Matter of the Application of Janet Stockard for
Admission to the Bar. The application for admission to the Bar of this
Court presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
granted. The Chief Justice would deny the application.
No. D-455. In the Matter of Disbarment of Monte Charles Phillips.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-472. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan Manning Miller.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-475. In the Matter of Bert Padell. The order of this Court en-
tered February 19, 1985, suspending Bert Padell from further practice
of law in this Court is vacated and the Rule to Show Cause issued Feb-
ruary 19, 1985, is discharged.
No. D-488. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur J. Rouse. It is or-
dered that Arthur J. Rouse, of West Nyack, New York, be suspended

MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1985
559
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, Plaintiff v. Commonwealth of Ken-
tucky. The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed.
The Report is adopted. Decree entered. The costs of this proceeding
shall be divided between the parties as recommended by the Special
Master.
No. 100, Original. Marie C. Webber, Plaintiff v. State of Oklahoma,
et al. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is denied.
No. 83-1925. Hillsborough County, Florida, et al., Appellants v.
Automated Medical Laboratories, Inc. The motion of the Solicitor Gen-
eral to permit Paul J. Larkin, Jr., Esquire, to present oral argument
pro hac vice is granted.
No. 84–310. In Re Robert J. Snyder, Petitioner. The motion of
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit to supplement
the joint appendix is granted.
No. 84–320. National Farmers Union Insurance Companies and

No. 84–1360. City of Renton, et al., Appellants v. Playtime Theatres,

lege of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Further consideration of
the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on
the merits.

denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall in this case and in
No. 84-5843, ante, with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 84-6123. Newton Collier Estes, Petitioner v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit denied. Justice White took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
No. 84-6154. Charles M. Albanese, Petitioner v. Illinois. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 84-6182. William Eutzy, Petitioner v. Florida. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 84-6286. Thomas Graves, Petitioner v. Sheriff Hester, et al. The
application for injunction addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to
the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 84-6317. In Re Michael C. Antonelli, Petitioner;
No. 84-6368. In Re Quintin Irving Brown, Petitioner; and
No. 84–6429. In Re Royal D. Ross, Petitioner. Petitions for writ of
habeas corpus are denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 84-6297. In Re George A. Hellwarth, Petitioner. Petition for
writ of mandamus is denied.

Automotive, Inc. The petitions for rehearing are denied.

OPINIONS
No. 84–76. Nell Hunter, et al., etc., Appellants v. Victor Underwood
and Carmen Edwards, etc. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-1748. Allis-Chalmers Corporation, Petitioner v. Roderick S.
Lueck. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 83–1075. Central Intelligence Agency, et al., Petitioners v. John
Cary Sims and Sidney M. Wolfe; and
No. 83-1249. John Cary Sims and Sidney M. Wolfe, Petitioners v.
Central Intelligence Agency and William J. Casey, Director, Central
Intelligence Agency. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part, reversed in part and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in the
result with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 84-68. Kerr-McGee Corporation, Petitioner v. Navajo Tribe of
Indians, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief

Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.

cia, 471 U. S. - (1985). Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief
Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1985
587
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 84-1281. Watson Marine Services, Inc., Appellant v. Kliebert
Educational Trust, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana,
Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 84-1380. Fred W. Allnutt, Sr., Appellant v. Maryland. Appeal
from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–1429. James Gilbert, Appellant v. University of Tennessee,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Divi-
sion. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–1928. Officer Swyka, et al., Petitioners v. Carl Lee Johnson.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Wilson v. Garcia, 471 U.S. (1985).
-
No. 84-706. Thomas Larson, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Francis W.
Fitzgerald. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Wilson v. Garcia, 471 U.S. (1985).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-470. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Alan Hayes. Dis-
barment order entered.

588
MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1985
No. 88, Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Texas,
et al. The joint petition for an order with respect to fees and expenses
of the Special Master is granted and it is ordered that the Honorable
Wade H. McCree, Jr., is awarded the sum of $50,000 as compensa-
tion for his services as Special Master and that his disbursements of
$2,246.74 is allowed. It is further ordered that the fees and disburse-
ments be paid in equal parts by the State of California, the State of
Texas, and William R. Lummis and First Interstate Bank of Nevada.
The order of Court entered December 13, 1982, is vacated.
This case having been dismissed on stipulation pursuant to Rule 53.1
of the Rules of this Court, it is further ordered that the Special Master
is hereby discharged.
No. 84-262. Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company,
Petitioner v. Pueblo of Santa Ana. The motion of respondent for leave
to file supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 84-310. In Re Robert J. Snyder, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to file reply brief, out-of-time, is granted.
No. 84-801. Midlantic National Bank, Petitioner v. New Jersey De-
partment of Environmental Protection; and
No. 84-805. Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Re-
sources Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. City of New York, et al.;
and Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Resources
Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. New Jersey Department of Envi-
ronmental Protection. The motion of Thomas H. Jackson for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 84-1198. Texas, Petitioner v. Sanford James McCullough. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 84-1244. Susan J. Davis, et al., Appellants v. Irwin C. Ban-
demer, et al. The motion of appellants to expedite and schedule oral
argument during 1984 Term is denied.
No. 84-6506. Billy Verlin Bewley, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. The appli-
cation for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court
is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-1236. Donald A. Cabana, Superintendent, Mississippi State
Penitentiary, et al., Petitioners v. Crawford Bullock, Jr. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit granted.

et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice

No. 84–1239. Margaret Young, Petitioner v. John F. Lehman, Jr.,
Secretary of the Navy. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice White,
Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor dissent and would grant the
petition for a writ of certiorari, vacate the judgment and remand the
case to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for
further consideration in light of Anderson v. City of Bessemer City,
North Carolina, 470 U.S. — (1985).

Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice Powell would grant

No. 84-5972. Jack Harry Smith, Petitioner v. Texas. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 84-6145. Liane Rowena Estrella Reyes, Petitioner v. Immigra-
tion and Naturalization Service. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Justice
White dissenting from denial. Because the decision in this case conflicts
with Bolanos-Hernandez v. INS, 749 F. 2d 1316 (9th Cir. 1984), I
would grant certiorari in this case.

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the Term upon the conclusion of the argu-
ments in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 29, 1985, until Mon-
day, May 13, 1985.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 84–755. United States, Petitioner v. Rosa Elvira Montoya de
Hernandez. Argued by Mr. Andrew Lewis Frey for the petitioner and
by Mr. Peter Marvin Horstman for the respondent.
No. 84-435. Robert Russell, Petitioner v. United States. Argued by
Mr. Julius Lucius Echeles for the petitioner and by Mr. Christopher J.
Wright for the respondent, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Nolan, if I may, before I open for oral arguments this afternoon,
a note for the record, of welcome to the President and Members of the
Constitutional Court of Austria, who are visiting and are our guests
today."
No. 84-9. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Doris Russell. Reargued by Mr. John E. Nolan, Jr., for the
petitioners and by Mr. Brad Naley Baker for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, April 29, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985
607
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-5795. Ernest Cornes, Appellant v. Marietta Faye Kellum,
et al. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84-6381. William Singer, Appellant v. John Justus Bodley, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1015. Johnnie K. Goodson, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Military
Appeals. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Military
Appeals for further consideration in light of Smith v. Illinois, 469 U. S.
(1984).
No. 84-1208. Joseph A. Murr, Petitioner v. Tennessee Board of Law
Examiners. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Tennessee, Middle Division. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division, for further consider-
ation in light of Supreme Court of New Hampshire v. Piper, 470 U. S.
(1985).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Joseph Afflerbach, Michael Cotton, John Cotton, Harvey B.
Annis and Murray Watson, Petitioners v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari in typewritten
form not in compliance with the Rules of the Court is denied.

608
MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985
No. - Lonnie B. Davis and G.E.C.C., Inc., Petitioners v. Amoco
Oil Co., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-473. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert White Hutchins.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-474. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Thomas Kozel.
William Thomas Kozel, of Santa Maria, California, having requested to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
is stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on February
19, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. D-490. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank E. Holtzman. It is
ordered that Frank E. Holtzman, of Southfield, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 35, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. States of
Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York,
New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South
Carolina, Georgia, and Florida. The Court having, by its decision of
February 19, 1985, overruled all exceptions to the Report of the Special
Master, adopted the Master's recommendations, and confirmed the Re-
port, the Supplemental Decree defining the Rhode Island-New York
Boundary is entered. Actual expenses of the Special Master to be borne
half by the United States and half by Rhode Island and New York
jointly. The Court retains jurisdiction to entertain such further pro-
ceedings, enter such orders, and issue such writs as from time to time
may be deemed necessary or advisable to effectuate and supplement
the decree and the rights of the respective parties.
No. 92, Original. State of Arkansas, Plaintiff v. State of Mississippi.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. The
parties have presented a stipulation for entry of the proposed decree.
The Report of the Special Master is adopted and final decree entered.
Certified copies of Exhibits A, B, C, and D to be filed with Custodian of
Official Land Records in Lee County, Arkansas and Tunica County,
Mississippi by attorneys general of the respective states.
No. 84-822. American National Bank and Trust Company of Chi-
cago, et al., Petitioners v. Haroco, Inc., et al. The motion of petitioners
to supplement the record is granted.

MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985
609
No. 84-1103. William Lloyd Hill, Petitioner v. A. L. Lockhart, Direc-
tor, Arkansas Department of Correction. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is granted. The mo-

Lassiter, Esquire, of Little Rock, Arkansas, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 84-1637. Calvin Holderman, Jr., Appellant v. United States; and
No. 84-1638. Calvin Holderman, Jr., Appellant v. United States.
The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to
the Court is denied.

Co., et al. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of the order
denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

Gingles, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the

noted limited to Questions I and III presented by the statement as to
jurisdiction.

MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985
ORDERS
617
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure be, and they are
hereby, amended by including therein a new Rule 49(e) and amend-
ments to Rules 6(e)(3)(A)(ii), 6(e)(3)(B) and (C), 11(c)(1), 12.1(f) 12.2(e),
35(b), 45(a) and 57.
2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1985, and shall govern all pro-
ceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings in criminal cases then pending. The
amendment to Rule 35(b) shall be effective until November 1, 1986,
when Section 215(b) of the Comprehensive Crime Control Act of 1984,
Pub. L. 98-473, approved October 12, 1984, 98 Stat. 2015, goes into
effect.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sections 3771
and 3772 of Title 18, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure be, and they are
hereby, amended by including therein a new Rule E(4)(f) to the Supple-
mental Rules for Certain Admiralty and Maritime Claims; amendments
to Rules 6(a), 45(d)(2), 52(a), 71A(h) and 83; amendments to Supple-
mental Admiralty Rules B(1) and C(3); and amendments to Official
Form 18-A.
2. That the foregoing addition to and amendments to the Federal
Rules of Civil Procedure, the Supplemental Rules for Certain Admi-
ralty and Maritime Claims, and the Official Form shall take effect on
August 1, 1985, and shall govern all proceedings in civil actions there-
after commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings
then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing addition to and amendments to the Fed-
eral Rules of Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sec-
tion 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. The the rules of procedure heretofore prescribed by the Court to
govern proceedings in bankruptcy cases be, and they are hereby,
amended by including therein the amendments to Rules 5002 and 5004.

618
MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985
2. That the aforementioned amendments to the Bankruptcy Rules
shall take effect on August 1, 1985, and shall govern all proceedings in
bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practi-
cable, proceedings in bankruptcy cases then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
these amendments to the Bankruptcy Rules to the Congress in accord-
ance with the provisions of Section 2075 of Title 28, United States
Code.

OPINIONS
No. 84-433. School Committee of the Town of Burlington, Massachu-
setts, et al., Petitioners v. Department of Education of the Common-
wealth of Massachusetts, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 84–261. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Petitioner v.
Gary Weintraub, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of the Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Justice
Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-1590. Robert Francis, Warden, Petitioner v. Raymond Lee
Franklin. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor
join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985
629
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
"
No. 84-1165. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph Benchimol. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 84–1440. Alwin E. Hopfmann, et al. Appellants v. Michael
Joseph Connolly, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1145. Thurman B. Lanton, Appellant v. Alabama. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84–1478. Alpha Blair, Appellant v. Larry Boulger. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of North Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-1583. Pauline Walber, dba Walber Construction Co., Appel-
lant v. United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

630
MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985
No. 84–1637. Calvin Holderman, Jr., Appellant v. United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 84-1638. Calvin Holderman, Jr., Appellant v. United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 84–6401. Donald Valway, et ux., Appellants v. Peter F. Kearns,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84–1476. Robert DePerte, et al., Appellants v.. Tribune Com-
pany, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida: The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-5636. Leon Alcorn, Petitioner v. Steve Smith, Warden. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in light of assertions set forth in petitioner's motion to vacate
filed April 26, 1985, and the response filed thereto.
No. 84-6410. Lem Davis Tuggle, Jr., Petitioner v. Virginia. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further consideration in
light of Ake v. Oklahoma, 470 U. S. ——— (1985).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Agnes Keller, Administratrix of the Estate of Charles
Keller, Deceased, Petitioner v. American Optical Company. The motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time is
denied.
No. D-294. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter L. Wolff. Disbar-
ment order entered.
1

MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985
631
No. D-462. In the Matter of Disbarment of James C. Collier. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-480. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren J. Black. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-489. In the Matter of Disbarment of James P. McGarry. It is
ordered that James P. McGarry, of Flushing, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-491. In the Matter of Disbarment of Maria Catherine
Pecoraro. It is ordered that Maria Catherine Pecoraro, of West Ches-
ter, Pennsylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring her to
show cause why she should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
No. D-492. In the Matter of Disbarment of John W. Surgent. It is
ordered that John W. Surgent, of Lake Ariel, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-1944. Holly Jensen, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Frances J.
Quaring. The motion of respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief
after argument is granted.
No. 84–262. Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company,
Petitioner v. Pueblo of Santa Ana. The motion of petitioner for leave to
file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 84-801. Midlantic National Bank, Petitioner v. New Jersey De-
partment of Environmental Protection; and
No. 84-805. Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta
Resources Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. City of New York, et al.;
and Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Resources
Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. New Jersey Department of Envi-
ronmental Protection. The motion of respondents for divided argument
is granted.
No. 84-1321. Crispus Nix, Warden, Petitioner v. Emanuel Charles
Whiteside. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Patrick Reilly Grady, Esquire, of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 84–1426. Robert Abrams, Attorney General of the State of New
York, Petitioner v. Michael McCray. The motion of respondent to expe-

632
MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985
dite further consideration of the petition for writ of certiorari and
consolidate with No. 84-6263, Batson v. Kentucky, is denied. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens would grant this motion.
No. 84-1447. William Z. Salcer, et al., Petitioners v. Envicon Equi-
ties Corp., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 84-6051. Stanley Edward Allen, Petitioner v. Georgia. The re-
spondent is requested to file a response to the petition for rehearing
within thirty days.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-1493. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Financial
Institution Employees of America, Local 1182, Chartered by United
Food and Commercial Workers International Union, AFL-CIO, et al.;
and
No. 84-1509. Seattle-First National Bank, Petitioner v. Financial In-
stitution Employees of America, etc., et al. Petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted
for oral argument.
No. 84–1288. John V. Evans, et al., Petitioners v. Jeff D., et al. The
motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 84-1480. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. David Wayne Greenfield. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit granted.
No. 84-1485. John Moran, Superintendent, Rhode Island Depart-
ment of Corrections, Petitioner v. Brian K. Burbine. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit granted.
No. 84-6646. Willie Lloyd Turner, Petitioner v. Allyn R. Sielaff,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted and petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.

MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985
OPINIONS
No. 83-2032. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Bernardo Rios-Pineda and Estarnilada Rios-Pineda De Rios. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice White. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 84-5108. Frank Liparota, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom
the Chief Justice joins. Justice White took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 83-859. California, Petitioner v. Charles R. Carney. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall join.
No. 83-2143. Tennessee, Petitioner v. Harvey J. Street. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern
District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Crimi-
nal Appeals for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Powell took no part
in the decision in this case.
