(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 14, 1985
659
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-859. Jesse de la Rosa, Applicant v. Raymond K. Procunier,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Wednesday, May 15,
1985, presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985
661
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1454. Mississippi Power & Light Company, Appellant v.
Louis A. Conerly, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice Blackmun would dismiss for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84-1605. Jack H. Brown & Co., Inc., Appellant v. Northwest
Sign Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1398. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Defense, et al.,
Petitioners v. Temistocles Ramirez de Arellano, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for reconsid-
eration of its opinion and judgment in light of the Foreign Assistance
and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1985, Pub. L. No. 98-473,
98 Stat. 1884, 1893-1894, and other events occurring since October 5,
1984.
No. 84–1418. Irma Pastrana de Caraballo, Petitioner v. Margaret M.
Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit with instructions to remand the case to the United States
District Court for the District of Puerto Rico with instructions to
remand the case to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for
review pursuant to Section 2(d)(2)(C) of the Social Security Disability
Benefits Reform Act of 1984.

662
MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-471. In the Matter of Disbarment of Cletus H. Brault, Jr. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-479. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Goffen. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-481. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene Gold. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-493. In the Matter of Disbarment of Raymond J. Surdut. It is
ordered that Raymond J. Surdut, of Providence, Rhode Island, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-1944. Holly Jensen, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Frances J.
Quaring. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a supplemental brief
after argument is granted.
No. 84–1244. Susan J. Davis, et al., Appellants v. Irwin C.
Bandemer, et al. The motion of Mexican American Legal Defense and
Educational Fund for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 84–1287. Louis Liphete, et al., Petitioners v. Merritt Stierheim,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 84–1545. Miller-Wohl Company, Inc., Appellant v. Commis-
sioner of Labor and Industry of Montana and Tamara L. Buley. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 84–1538. Alexandra Fisher, et al., Appellants v. City of Berke-
ley, California, et al. The motion of California Chamber of Commerce
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of West-
ern Mobilehome Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 84-6598. George T. Knoblauch, Petitioner v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 10, 1985,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U. S. (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
-

MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985
663
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 84-1484. Wisconsin Department of Industry, Labor and Human
Relations, et al., Appellants v. Gould, Inc. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. In this case probable
jurisdiction is noted.
No. 84–1379. Eugene F. Diamond and Jasper F. Williams, Appel-
lants v. Allan G. Charles, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted. The case is set for oral argument in tandem with No. 84-495,
Thornburgh v. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists:
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 83-6887. Mark E. Quigley, Petitioner v. Massachusetts. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts
denied.
No. 84-995. James Massa, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 84–1265. Duane Skinner, Petitioner v. United States. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 84-1200. Edwin Meese, III, Attorney General of the United
States, et al., Petitioners v. Henry W. Segar, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit denied.
No. 84-1257. Richard L. Glover, etc., Petitioner v. United Grocers,
Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 84–1344. Saginaw Mining Company, Petitioner v. Lewis Gibas,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 84-1351. George W. Akootchook, et al, Petitioners v. United
States, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 84-1365. Public Utility District No. 1 of Chelan County, Wash-

Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985

OPINIONS
No. 83–1632. Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc. and The Reader's Di-
gest Association, Inc., Petitioners v. Nation Enterprises and The
Nation Associates, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice White and Justice Marshall
join.
No. 84-465. Lee Roy Black, Director, Missouri Department of Cor-
rections and Human Resources and Dick D. Moore, Chairman, Missouri
Board of Probation and Parole, Petitioners v. Nicholas J. Romano. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Marshall

MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985
673
with whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice Powell took no part in the
decision of this case.
No. 83-2136. Connecticut, Department of Income Maintenance, Peti-
tioner v. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary, Department of Health and
Human Services, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.
No. 83–1329. Joseph Ponte, Superintendent, Massachusetts Correc-
tional Institution, Walpole, Petitioner v. John Real. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Blackmun joins as to Part II. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice Powell took no part in the
decision of this case.
No. 83–2097. Burger King Corporation, Appellant v. John Rudze-
wicz. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice White joins. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of
this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1985
677
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1571. Myron H. O'Keefe, etc., Appellant v. County of Henne-
pin. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-478. In the Matter of Disbarment of Anna Cotton Hailey. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-487. In the Matter of Disbarment of Irving Tabman. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. 102, Original. State of Indiana, Plaintiff v. United States of
America, United States House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill,
Jr., Benjamin J. Guthrie, Jack Russ and James T. Malloy. The motion
to amend the proposed complaint is granted. The motion for leave to file
a bill of complaint is denied.
No. 84-773. Michael Bender, et al., Petitioners v. Williamsport Area
School District, et al. The motion of respondents for divided argument
to permit American Jewish Congress to present oral argument as ami-
cus curiae is denied.
No. 84-1044. Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Appellant v. Public
Utilities Commission of California, et al. The motion of the parties to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 84-1361. United States, Petitioner v. Kenneth Moses Loud
Hawk, et al. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Kenneth Saul Stern, Esquire, of Milwaukie, Oregon, is ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondents in this case.
No. 84-6743. Talakkottur R. David, Petitioner v. American Tele-
phone & Telegraph Company, et al. The application for stay addressed
to Justice Blackmun and referred to the Court is denied.

678
TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1985
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 84–1538. Alexandra Fisher, et al., Appellants v. City of Berke-
ley, California, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
motion of California Association of Realtors for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of California Building Industry
Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. In this
case probable jurisdiction is noted limited to Question 1 presented by
the statement as to jurisdiction. The appeal as to Question 2 presented
by the statement as to jurisdiction is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84–1580. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph Inadi. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit granted.
No. 84-1586. Edward Malley and Rhode Island, Petitioners v. James
R. Briggs and Louisa Briggs. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted.
No. 84-1531. Michigan, Petitioner v. Robert Bernard Jackson; and
No. 84–1539. Michigan, Petitioner v. Rudy Bladel. The motions of re-
spondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis are granted. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michigan granted. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-1141. Michael Holland, Arnold Holland, Paul Murphy, and
Lawrence John Holland, Petitioners v. United States. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit denied.

Florida, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.
No. 84–1376. Grim Hotel Company, et al., Petitioners v. William E.
Brock, Secretary of Labor, United States Department of Labor and 177
Named Employee Plaintiffs. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.

OPINIONS
No. 83-1961. Landreth Timber Company, Petitioner v. Ivan K.
Landreth, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens in this case and in No. 84-165, Gould, W. George v.
Ruefenacht, Max, post.
No. 84-165. W. George Gould, Petitioner v. Max A. Ruefenacht,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens in this case and in No. 83–1961, Landreth
Timber Co. v. Landreth, Ivan K., ante.
No. 83–2166. Philip Q. Zauderer, Appellant v. Office of Disciplinary
Counsel of the Supreme Court of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Ohio. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part, and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part
with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part with whom The Chief Justice and
Justice Rehnquist join. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of
this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 3, 1985 at 10 o'clock.
No. A-903. Marvin François, Applicant v. Louie L. Wainwright, Sec-
retary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Wednesday, May 29,
1985, presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court is
denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall joins.
1.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1985
691
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1609. Joan L. Murphy, et al., Appellants v. Pennsylvania
Human Relations Commission, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 84–1763. Pauline Walber, etc., appellant v. United States De-
partment of Housing and Urban Development. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-1764. Pauline Walber, etc, appellant v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 84-6529. Martha B. Gaunce, Appellant v. Idaho. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Idaho. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-484. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Edward Wollrab.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-485. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alex Gerhart Logan, III.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-486. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leonard Adolph Delk.
Leonard Adolph Delk, of Long Beach, California, having requested to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the

692
MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1985
Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on March
25, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. D-494. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Douglas Ed-
wards. It is ordered that Robert Douglas Edwards, of Destin, Florida,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-495. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leon Dicker. It is
ordered that Leon Dicker, of New York, New York, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-496. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles Kilburn Hyter. It
is ordered that Charles Kilburn Hyter, of Hutchinson, Kansas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-497. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Maulsby Moore.
It is ordered that Michael Maulsby Moore, of Everett, Washington, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-498. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold G. Slone. It is
ordered that Harold G. Slone, of Lexington, Kentucky, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84-6646. Willie Lloyd Turner, Petitioner v. Allyn R. Sielaff,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. The motion for appoint-
ment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that J. Lloyd Snook III,
Esquire, of Charlottesville, Virginia, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
APPEALS―JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 84-1601. Aetna Life Insurance Co., Appellant v. Margaret W.
Lavoie and Roger J. Lavoie, Sr. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Alabama. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction is post-
poned to the hearing of the case on the merits.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
693
No. 84-782. South Carolina, et al., Petitioners v. Catawba Indian
Tribe of South Carolina. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 84-1513. California, Petitioner v. Dante Carlo Ciraolo. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District, granted limited to Question 1 presented by the
petition.
No. 84-1602. Jack Anderson, et al., Petitioners v. Liberty Lobby,
Inc. and Willis A. Carto. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted
limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.
No. 84-1636. R. C. Marshall, Superintendent, Southern Ohio Correc-
tional Facility, Petitioner v. James Michael Mathews. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit granted.
No. 84-6470. Robert Davidson, Petitioner v. Joseph Cannon, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted and the petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit are granted. The case is set for
oral argument in tandem with No. 84-5872, Daniels v. Williams.

certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nevada denied.

OPINIONS
No. 84-320. National Farmers Union Insurance Companies and
Lodge Grass School District No. 27, Petitioners v. Crow Tribe of Indi-
ans, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment is reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 84-435. Robert Russell, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 83-1842. Jonathan Garrett, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Concurring
opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens
with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Justice Powell
took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83–1919. City of Oklahoma City, Petitioner v. Rose Marie Tuttle,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice Rehnquist announced the judgment of the Court, and de-
livered the opinion of the Court with respect to Part II, and an opinion
with respect to Part III, in which the Chief Justice, Justice White, and
Justice O'Connor join. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Marshall and Justice
Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Powell
took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-2161. Montana, et al., Petitioners v. Blackfeet Tribe of Indi-
ans. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Rehnquist and Justice
Stevens join.
No. 84-325. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Appellant v.
Massachusetts; and
No. 84-356. Travelers Insurance Company, Appellant v. Massachu-
setts. Appeals from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.

MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1985
707
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Powell took
no part in the decision of these cases.
No. 83-1925. Hillsborough County, Florida, et al., Appellants v.
Automated Medical Laboratories, Inc. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 4, 1985
709
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Justice
Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 83-1660. Charles M. Atkins, Commissioner of the Massachusetts
Department of Public Welfare, Petitioner v. Gill Parker, et al.; and
No. 83-6381. Gill Parker, et al., Petitioners v. John R. Block, Secre-
tary, Department of Agriculture, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins as to Part I. Dissenting Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 83-812. George C. Wallace, Governor of the State of Alabama,
et al., Appellants v. Ishmael Jaffree, et al.; and
No. 83-929. Douglas T. Smith, et al., Appellants v. Ishmael Jaffree,
et al. Appeals for the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring
opinion by Justice Powell. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 84–592. Norman Williams and Susan Levine, Appellants v. Ver-
mont, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vermont. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor
join. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-2129. Barbara R. Schreiber, Petitioner v. Burlington North-
ern, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief
Justice. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 10, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1985
711
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 83-1952. Pan American World Airways, Inc., Appellant v.
George Puchert, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84-1150. Mark A. Humphrey and Fredd J. Haas, dba Humphrey
& Haas, Appellants v. Committee on Professional Ethics and Conduct
of the Iowa State Bar Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Iowa. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Supreme Court of Iowa for further consideration in light of Zauderer v.
Office of Disciplinary Counsel of the Supreme Court of Ohio, 471 U.S.
(1985). Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor would note proba-
ble jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 84–1248. Village Publishing Corporation, Appellant v. North
Carolina Department of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 84-1553. Ramiro Arango, Appellant v. Florida Bar. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-1682. Frank Cicero, Appellant v. New York. Appeal from the
Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Fourth Judicial
Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 84-6572. Lyle H. Prenzler, Appellant v. Josephine M. Prenzler.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the

712
MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1985
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 84-6579. Stanley March, Appellant v. Catherine Ann March.
Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1255. Alpha Beta Company, et al., Petitioners v. Superior
Court of California, County of Alameda, (Rita Nahm, Real Party in
Interest). On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of
California, First Appellate District. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District, for further con-
sideration in light of Allis-Chalmers Corporation v. Lueck, 471 U.S.
(1985).
No. 84-1663. Vernice C. Nichelson, Petitioner v. Quaker Oats Com-
pany. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Anderson v. City of Bessemer City, North Carolina,
470 U.S.
-
(1985).
No. 84-6159. Russell Allen Kilpatrick, Petitioner v. Margaret M.
Heckler, Secretary of Health & Human Services. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit with instructions to remand the case to the United
States District Court for the District of Maryland with instructions to
remand the case to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for re-
view pursuant to Section 2(d)(2)(C) of the Social Security Disability
Benefits Reform Act of 1984.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-884. Janice M. Hayes, Applicant v. Helen C. Cannon. The
application for stay and/or other relief addressed to Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court is denied.

No. D-477. In the Matter of Disbarment of John B. Kennedy. Dis-

No. D-499. In the Matter of Disbarment of Felix Saul Jacob. It is
ordered that Felix Saul Jacob, of Towson, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–500. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harris N. Walters. It is
ordered that Harris N. Walters, of Southampton, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-501. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles A. Chartier. It is
ordered that Charles A. Chartier, of Junction City, Kansas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-502. In the Matter of Disbarment of Benjamin Sloan Atkins.
It is ordered that Benjamin Sloan Atkins, of Atlanta, Georgia, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

cases probable jurisdiction is noted. The cases are consolidated and a
total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

OPINIONS
No. 84–262. Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company,
Petitioner v. Pueblo of Santa Ana. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and
Justice Blackmun join. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 83-1911. Christopher L. Lowe, et al., Petitioners v. Securities
and Exchange Commission. On writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice White concurring in the result with whom the Chief Justice and
Justice Rehnquist join. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of
this case.
No. 84-363. Northeast Bancorp, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Board of
Governors of the Federal Reserve System, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 11, 1985
733
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 83–6607. Bobby Caldwell, Petitioner v. Mississippi. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment reversed in
part and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice
Marshall delivered the opinion of the Court except as to Part IV-A.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice White join. Justice Powell took no part in the
decision of this case.
No. 83-1368. Northwest Wholesale Stationers, Inc., Petitioner v.
Pacific Stationery and Printing Co. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the judgment of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
Justice Marshall and Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 84–679. Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, Incorporated, Peti-
tioner v. Carl F. Berner, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. The Chief Justice concurs in the judgment.
Justice Marshall took no part in the decision of this case.
☑
Adjourned until Monday, June 17, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985
735
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-315. Leonard G. Leverson, Appellant v. William H. Conway,
Commissioner, Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles. The petition.
for rehearing is granted. The order entered October 29, 1984, is va-
cated. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Vermont for further consideration in light of Williams
v. Vermont, 472 U.S. (1985).
-
No. 84-1517. Thomas M. Fahey, etc., Appellant v. David Axelrod,
Commissioner of Health of the State of New York. Appeal from the Ap-
pellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial Depart-
ment. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 84-1817. Jude Thibault, Appellant v. Carl H. Weiss, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 84-1630. Blue Cross Hospital Service, Inc. of Missouri, et al.,
Appellants v. J. H. Frappier, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Missouri. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the Supreme Court of Missouri for further consideration in light of Met-
ropolitan Life Insurance Co. v. Massachusetts, 471 U.S. ——— (1985).
No. 84-1818. Donald K. Williams, et ux., Appellants v. Ann Marie
Govine, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Connecticut. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-6021. Richard B. Sanders, Petitioner v. John Robinson, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

736
MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985
for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of National Farmers Union Insurance Cos. v. Crow Tribe of Indians,
471 U.S. (1985).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-831. Johnny Klevenhagen, et al., Sheriff of Harris County,
Texas, et al., Applicants v. Lawrence R. Alberti, et al. The application
for stay of orders of the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Texas pending appeal to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-913. Christine Keno, Applicant v. Richard Jones. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. D-503. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick A. Smith. It is
ordered that Frederick A. Smith, of Truth or Consequences, New Mex-
ico, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 35, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. States of
Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York,
New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South
Carolina, Georgia and Florida. The Report of the Special Master on the
Massachusetts boundary is received and ordered filed. Exceptions to
the Report, with supporting briefs, may be filed by the parties within
45 days. Replies thereto, with supporting briefs, may be filed within 30
days.
No. 101, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Plaintiff v. State
of Alabama, et al. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is
denied.
No. 83-1807. Eastern Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Robert F. Mah-
foud, etc. The case is restored to the calendar for reargument.
No. 83–2004. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Zenith Radio Corporation, et al. The motion of Government
of Japan for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 84-773. Michael Bender, et al., Petitioners v. Williamsport Area
School District, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to

MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985
737
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens would deny this motion.
No. 84–1044. Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Appellant v. Public
Utilities Commission of California, et al. The motion of appellees To-
ward Utility Rate Normalization, et al. for divided argument is denied.
Justice Blackmun and Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 84-1851. Edgar Hardin Gillock, Petitioner v. United States. The
application to recall and stay mandate addressed to Justice Marshall
and referred to the Court is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 84-978. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Robert Hunt,
Administrator of New Jersey Spill Compensation Fund, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. In this case probable jurisdic-
tion is noted.
No. 84-780. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Appellants v. Stephen J. Roy, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania. In
this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The case is set for oral argu-
ment in tandem with No. 84–1097, Goldman v. Weinberger.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-1160. Bertold J. Pembaur, Petitioner v. City of Cincinnati, et
al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit granted.
No. 84–1529. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. American Hospital Association, et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit granted.
No. 84-1644. Golden State Transit Corporation, Petitioner v. City of
Los Angeles. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 84-1686. Marie D. Sorenson, etc., Petitioner v. Secretary of the
Treasury of the United States and United States. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
granted.
No. 84–1097. S. Simcha Goldman, Petitioner v. Caspar W. Weinber-
ger, Secretary of Defense, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

738
MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted. The case is set for oral argument in tandem with No. 84-780,
Heckler v. Roy.
No. 84-1640. United States, Petitioner v. Marshall Mechanik, et al.;
No. 84-1700. Jerome Otto Lill, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 84-1704. Marshall Mechanik, aka Michael Patrick Flanagan, Pe-
titioner v. United States. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petitions for writs
of certiorari in Nos. 84-1640 and 84-1700 are granted. The petition for
writ of certiorari in No. 84-1704 is granted limited to Question 1 pre-
sented by the petition. The cases are consolidated and a total of one
hour is allotted for oral argument.

ORDER
It is ordered that Joseph F. Spaniol, Jr., be appointed Clerk of the
Court to succeed Alexander L. Stevas, effective at the commencement
of business, August 1, 1985, and that he take the oath of office as re-
quired by statute.

745
It is ordered that Stephen G. Margeton be appointed Librarian of the

business July 15, 1985, and that he take the oath of office as required by

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Wednesday, June 19, 1985, until
Monday, June 24, 1985.

OPINIONS
No. 84–127. Richardson-Merrell, Inc., Petitioner v. Anne Elisabeth
Koller, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions to dismiss the
appeal for want of jurisdiction. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 84-438. Superintendent, Massachusetts Correctional Institution,
Walpole, Petitioner v. Gerald Hill and Joseph Crawford. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and
dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
join.
No. 84-778. Maryland, Petitioner v. Baxter Macon. On writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Special Appeals for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins.
No. 83-1545. Western Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Charles G. Cris-
well, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

750
MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 84-5743. Brian Keith Baldwin, Petitioner v. Alabama. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
join.
No. 84-518. Robert W. Johnson, et al., Petitioners v. Mayor and City
Council of Baltimore, et al.; and
No. 84-710. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Petitioner
v. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Marshall.
No. 83–1944. Holly Jensen, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Frances J.
Quaring. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Justice Powell took
no part in the decision of this case.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 19, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1985
751
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84–510. Aspen Skiing Company, Petitioner v. Aspen Highlands
Skiing Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Justice White took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 82-2157. Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pen-
sion Fund, et al., Petitioners v. Central Transport, Inc., et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehn-
quist join.
No. 84-28. Donald C. Brockett, Appellant v. Spokane Arcades, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 84–143. Kenneth Eikenberry, Attorney General of Washington,
et al., Appellants v. J-R Distributors, Inc., et al. Appeals from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Bren-
nan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Powell took no part in
the decision of these cases.
No. 84-335. John N. Mitchell, Petitioner v. Keith Forsyth. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by the
Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part with
whom the Chief Justice joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Powell took

752
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1985
no part in the decision of this case. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–476. Robert McDonald, Petitioner v. David I. Smith. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice
Blackmun join. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

Adjourned until Monday, June 24, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985
-753
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–1714. John H. Slingerland, Appellant v. Paul N. Olson, Chair-
man, Vermont Board of Bar Examiners, et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
No. 84–6694. Joseph Williams and Y. L. Jones, Appellants v. Grand
Lodge of Freemasonry, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI
SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–1192. GAF Corporation, Petitioner v. James K. J. Cheng. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit with instructions to dismiss the
appeal for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84-5092. John Earl Booker, Petitioner v. Mississippi. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The petition for rehear-
ing is granted. The order entered October 1, 1984 denying certiorari is
vacated. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi
for further consideration in light of Caldwell v. Mississippi, 472 U.S.
(1985).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-914. William Thomas Robinson, Applicant v. United States.
The application for stay of mandate addressed to Justice Marshall and
referred to the Court is denied.

754
MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985
No. D-504. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Norman Howard.
It is ordered that James Norman Howard, of Lakeside Park, Kentucky,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-505. In the Matter of Disbarment of Calvin J. Hurd. It is or-
dered that Calvin J. Hurd, of Elizabeth, New Jersey, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-506. In the Matter of Disbarment of Phillip C. Daniels, Jr. It
is ordered that Phillip C. Daniels, Jr., of Merchantsville, New Jersey,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-507. In the Matter of Disbarment of Burnett Roth. It is or-
dered that Burnett Roth, of Miami Beach, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-508. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth Dale Short. It is
ordered that Kenneth Dale Short, of Ellicott City, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83-2004. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Zenith Radio Corporation, et al. The motion of Governments
of Australia, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 84-468. City of Cleburne, Texas, et al., Petitioners v. Cleburne
Living Center, et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a supple-
mental brief after argument is granted.
No. 84-801. Midlantic National Bank, Petitioner v. New Jersey De-
partment of Environmental Protection; and
No. 84-805. Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta
Resources Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. City of New York, et al.;
and Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Resources
Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. New Jersey Department of Envi-
ronmental Protect. The motion of petitioner Midlantic National Bank
for divided argument is granted.

MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985
755
No. 84–1076. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Appellant
v. State Oil and Gas Board of Mississippi and Coastal Exploration, Inc.,
et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted. The
motion of appellees State Oil and Gas Board of Mississippi, et al. for
divided argument is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of these motions.
No. 84-1513. California, Petitioner v. Dante Carlo Ciraolo. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Marshall W. Krause, Esquire, of Larkspur, California, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case pursuant to Rule 46.6 of
the Rules of this Court.
No. 84-5786. Frank M. Miller, Jr., Petitioner v. Peter J. Fenton,
Superintendent, Rahway State Prison, et al. The motion of petitioner
for divided argument is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 84-1491. Philadelphia Newspapers, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Maurice S. Hepps, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylva-
nia, Eastern District. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 84-871. Louisiana Public Service Commission, Appellant v.
Federal Communications Commission, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Further consideration
of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case
on the merits. The case is consolidated with No. 84-889, California v.
Federal Commucations Commission; No. 84-1054, Public Utilities
Commission of Ohio v. Federal Communications Commission; and
No. 84–1069, Florida Public Service Commission v. Federal Commu-
nications Commission and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argu-
ment. The cases are set for oral argument in tandem with No. 84–1362,
Public Service Commission of Maryland v. Chesapeake and Potomac
Telephone Company of Maryland. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 84-1616. Parsons Steel, Inc., et al. Petitioners v. First Alabama
Bank of Montgomery and Edward Herbert. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
granted.
No. 84-1728. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Peti-
tioner v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. Petition for writ

756
MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit granted.
No. 84-889. California and Public Utilities Commission of California,
et al., Petitioners v. Federal Communications Commission and United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted. The case is consolidated with
No. 84-871, Louisiana Public Service Commission v. Federal Commu-
nications Commission; No. 84-1054, Public Utilities Commission of
Ohio v. Federal Communications Commission; and No. 84-1069, Flor-
ida Public Service Commission v. Federal Communications Commis-
sion and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument. The cases are
set for oral argument in tandem with No. 84–1362, Public Service Com-
mission of Maryland v. Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company
of Maryland. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this order.
No. 84-1054. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, et al., Petitioners
v. Federal Communications Commission, et al. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
granted. The case is consolidated with No. 84-871, Louisiana Pub-
lic Service Commission v. Federal Communications Commission;
No. 84-889, California v. Federal Communications Commission; and
No. 84-1069, Florida Public Service Commission v. Federal Commu-
nications Commission and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argu-
ment. The cases are set for oral argument in tandem with No. 84–1362,
Public Service Commission of Maryland v. Chesapeake and Potomac
Telephone Company of Maryland. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 84-1069. Florida Public Service Commission, Petitioner v.
Federal Communications Commission, et al. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
granted. The case is consolidated with No. 84-871, Louisiana Pub-
lic Service Commission v. Federal Communications Commission;
No. 84-889, California v. Federal Communications Commission; and
No. 84-1054, Public Utilities Commission of Ohio v. Federal Commu-
nications Commission and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argu-
ment. The cases are set for oral argument in tandem with No. 84–1362,
Public Service Commission of Maryland v. Chesapeake and Potomac
Telephone Company of Maryland. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.

No. 84-1362. Public Service Commission of Maryland, Petitioner v.

Communications Commission; No. 84-889, California v. Federal
Communications Commission; No. 84-1054, Public Utilities Com-
mission of Ohio v. Federal Communications Commission; and

part in the consideration or decision of this order.

OPINIONS
No. 83–1624. United States, Petitioner v. James Vincent Albertini.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 83-1673. Loretta Cornelius, Acting Director, Office of Personnel
Management, Petitioner v. Allison E. Nutt, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Brennan joins. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
No. 84-310. In Re Robert J. Snyder, Petitioner. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the
Chief Justice. Justice Blackmun took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 84-231. Alvin D. Hooper and Mary N. Hooper, Appellants v.
Bernalillo County Assessor. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
Mexico. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
of New Mexico for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
1

MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985
771
of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join. Justice Powell took no part in the
decision of this case.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 26, 1985 at 10 o'clock.

Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of execution
of the sentence of death scheduled for Tuesday, June 25, 1985, pre-

nied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

OPINIONS
No. 84-233. Phillips Petroleum Company, Petitioner v. Irl Shutts,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas. Judgment
affirmed in part, reversed in part and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Stevens con-
curring in part and dissenting in part. Justice Powell took no part in the
decision of this case.
No. 84-5240. Marie Lucie Jean, et al., Petitioners v. Alan Nelson,
Commissioner, Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice
Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-18. Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., Petitioner v. Greenmoss Build-
ers, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Vermont. Judg-
ment affirmed. Justice Powell announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Con-
nor joined. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens join.
No. 84-498. United States, Petitioner v. National Bank of Com-
merce. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Powell with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Ste-
vens join.
No. 83-1158. Estate of Donald E. Thornton and Connecticut, Peti-
tioners v. Caldor, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Connecticut. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concur-

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 26, 1985
ring opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Dissenting statement by Justice Rehnquist.

OPINIONS
No. 84-9. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, et al.,
Petitioners v. Doris Russell. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with whom Justice White,
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 83–1894. Pattern Makers' League of North America, AFL-CIO,
et al., Petitioners v. National Labor Relations Board, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring
opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens.
No. 84-861. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Inter-
national Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor
join.
No. 83–1437. Jeffrey Marek, Thomas Wadycki and Lawrence Rhode,
Petitioner v. Alfred W. Chesny, Individually and as Administrator of
the Estate of Steven Chesny, Deceased. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief

778
THURSDAY, JUNE 27, 1985
Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by
Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 84–194. United States, Petitioner v. Louise Shearer, Individ-
ually and as Administratrix for the Estate of Vernon Shearer, De-
ceased. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. The Chief Justice delivered the opinion of the Court, except
as to Part II-A. Statement by Justice Brennan concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens join. Statement by Justice Marshall concurring in the judg-
ment. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

tice O'Connor with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
join.

Mental Health, Petitioners v. Douglas James Scanlon. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

Petitioners v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting statement by Justice White. Justice Powell took no part in
the decision of this case.

Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
781
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–1591. Susan Marie Breaux Boudreaux, Appellant v. Agnes
Boutte Grice. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84–6755. Gabriel A. Bury, Appellant v. City of Lakeland, Flor-
ida, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–494. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Machin-
ists Local 1327, International Association of Machinists, etc., et al.; and
No. 84-528. Viola Lapinski, et al., Petitioners v. Machinists Local
1327, International Association of Machinists, etc., et al. On petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petitions for writs of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the cases are remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Pattern Makers' League of North America v. National Labor Rela-
tions Board, 473 U. S. (1985).
No. 84–1324. R. A. Adams and Joseph Mongiello, Petitioners v. Rob-
ert M. Jasinski. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of cer-
tiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Mitchell v. Forsyth, 472 U. S. (1985).
-
No. 84-1756. City of Shepherdsville, Kentucky, et al., Petitioners v.
Paul Dale Rymer. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-

782
MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
consideration in light of City of Oklahoma City v. Tuttle, 471 U. S.
(1985).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . In the Matter of Admission of Thomas A. Howard. On
application for admission to the Bar of this Court. The application for
admission to the Bar of this Court presented to Justice O'Connor and by
her referred to the Court is granted. Dissenting opinion by by the Chief
Justice.
No. A-928. William Howard Pugh, Applicant v. Florida. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. A-944. Tonni Faber and Tammi Faber, Applicants v. Linda
Faber Fargnoli and Donald Faber. The application for stay of the order
of the Appellate Divsion, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial
Department, presented to Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-490. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank E. Holtzman. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. 92, Original. State of Arkansas, Plaintiff v. State of Mississippi.
The request of the Special Master for award of costs and compensation
is granted and he is awarded a total of $32,110.74 to be divided equally
by the parties. The Special Master is hereby discharged.
No. 79, Original. State of Oklahoma, Plaintiff v. State of Arkansas.
The Report of the Special Master is adopted and approved as submit-
ted. Decree entered and judgment entered in favor of Arkansas and
claims of Oklahoma dismissed with prejudice. Costs are taxed against
Oklahoma. The Special Master is discharged.
No. 82-1889. Springfield Township School District, et al., Petitioners
v. Madelin H. Knoll. The motion of respondent to retax costs is granted
and the parties are to bear their own costs. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 83–2004. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Zenith Radio Corporation, et al. The motion of petitioners to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted and counsel shall
file with the Clerk nine copies of the record that was before the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The motion of the Solici-

MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
783
tor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae,
for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument is
denied.
No. 84-1244. Susan J. Davis, et al., Appellants v. Irwin C. Bande-
mer, et al. The application for stay of the December 13, 1984 order of
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana
presented to Justice Stevens and by him referred to the Court is
denied.
No. 84-1531. Michigan, Petitioner v. Robert Bernard Jackson. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
James Krogsrud, Esquire, of Detroit, Michigan, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 84–1539. Michigan, Petitioner v. Rudy Bladel. The motion for ap-
pointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Ronald J. Bretz,
Esquire, of Lansing, Michigan, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent in this case.
No. 84-1745. William J. Schilling, etc., Petitioner v. Telegraph Sav-
ings and Loan Association of Chicago, et al. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 84–1747. Cleo F. Shoultz, Petitioner v. Monfort of Colorado,
Inc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 84-6868. Reno Valentino, Petitioner v. Superior Court of the
County of Contra Costa. The application for stay addressed to the Chief
Justice and referred to the Court is denied.

Soto-Lopez, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

versity of New York, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.

tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

OPINIONS
No. 84-497. Lee M. Thomas, Administrator, United States Environ-
mental Protection Agency, Appellant v. Union Carbide Agricultural
Products Co., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Southern District of New York. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the District Court for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by
Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring
in the judgment.
No. 84-755. United States, Petitioner v. Rosa Elvira Montoya de
Hernandez. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Stevens
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 84-468. City of Cleburne, Texas, et al., Petitioners v. Cleburne
Living Center, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, vacated in
part, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-

MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
795
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief
Justice joins. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment in
part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 84–648. Sedima, S.P.R.L., Petitioner v. Imrex Company, Inc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Mar-
shall in this case and in No. 84-822, American National Bank and
Trust Company of Chicago, et al. v. Haroco, Inc., et al., post, with
whom Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun and Justice Powell join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Powell.
No. 83-990. School District of the City of Grand Rapids, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Phyllis Ball, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Brennan. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the judg-
ment in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Justice O'Connor con-
curring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting
opinion by Justice White in this case and in No. 84-237, Aguilar v.
Felton, No. 84-238, Secretary, U. S. Dept. of Education v. Felton, and
No. 84-239, Chancellor of Bd. of Ed. of N. Y. v. Felton, post. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 84-237. Yolanda Aguilar, et al., Appellants v. Betty-Louise
Felton, et al.;
No. 84–238. Secretary, United States Department of Education,
Appellant v. Betty-Louise Felton, et al.; and
No. 84-239. Chancellor of the Board of Education of City of New
York, Appellant v. Betty-Louise Felton, et al. Appeals from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Appeals dismissed.
Treating the papers as petitions for for writs of certiorari, see 28
U. S. C. Sec. 2103, we granted the petitions for writs of certiorari.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by
Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting
opinion by Justice White in these cases and in No. 83–990, School
District of Grand Rapids v. Ball, ante. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice
Rehnquist joins as to Parts II and III.

796
MONDAY, JULY 1, 1985
No. 84-822. American National Bank and Trust Company of Chi-
cago, et al., Petitioners v. Haroco, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Marshall in this case and in No. 84-822, Ameri-
can Nat. Bk. & Trust v. Haroco, Inc., ante.
The Chief Justice said:
"Tomorrow, Tuesday, July 2, 1985, the Court will announce all the
remaining opinions ready during the Term of the Court."
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 84-1923. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Petitioners v. City of New York, et al. The application
for a partial stay of the judgment of the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of New York, case No. CV-83-0457, as set
forth in the January 31, 1984 order, presented to Justice Marshall and
by him referred to the Court, is granted pending the disposition by this
Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall
continue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.
