TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
797
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1292. Stearns Coal and Lumber Company, Inc., Appellant v.
Kentucky Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Cabinet.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 84-1343. Dempster and Pauline Ferguson, et al., Appellants v.
G. Hugh Wamble and Verline Cobbins, et al.; and
No. 84-1355. William J. Bennett, Secretary, United States Depart-
ment of Education, et al., Appellants v. G. Hugh Wamble, et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Western District
of Missouri. The motion of Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The appeals are
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 84–1528. G. Hugh Wambe, et al., Appellants v. William J. Ben-
nett, Secretary of the United States Department of Education, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western District
of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
- No. 84-604. Martin J. Joel, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. John Cirrito,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Sedima, S.P.R.L. v. Imrex Co., 473 U. S.
(1985) and American National Bank v. Haroco, Inc., 473 U. S.
(1985).
-
No. 84-657. Bankers Trust Company, Petitioner v. Daniel Rhoades,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Sedima, S.P.R.L. v. Imrex Co., 473 U. S.

798
TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
(1985) and American National Bank v. Haroco, Inc., 473 U. S.
(1985).
No. 84-1033. United States, Petitioner v. William H. Pflaumer. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of United States
v. Bagley, 473 U. S. (1985).
-
No. 84-1084. Tiffany Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Alexander Grant
& Company; and
No. 84-1222. Farrell Kahn, Petitioner v. Alexander Grant & Com-
pany. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petitions for writs of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the cases are remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Sedima, S.P.R.L. v. Imrex Co., 473 U. S.
(1985) and American National Bank v. Haroco, Inc., 473.U. S.
(1985). Justice Blackmun would deny the petitions for writs of
certiorari.
No. 84-1500. ContiCommodity Services, Inc., Petitioner v. William
T. Schor, et al.; and
No. 84-1519. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Petitioner v.
William T. Schor, et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The peti-
tions for writs of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the cases are remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Thomas
v. Union Carbide Agricultural Products Co., 473 U. S. (1985).
CERTIORARI GRANTED
-
No. 84-1279. Delaware, Petitioner v. Robert E. Van Arsdall. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Delaware is
granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-722. David Alan Long, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
· Ninth Circuit denied.

TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
799
No. 84-5554. Rodrigo Henao-Castano, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that L. Ralph Mecham be appointed Director of the
Administrative Office of the United States Courts to succeed William
E. Foley, effective July 15, 1985, pursuant to the provisions of Sec. 601
of Title 28 of the United States Code.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until the first Monday in
October, 1985, at which time the October 1984 Term will adjourn.
OPINIONS
No. 84-312. Loretta Cornelius, Acting Director, Office of Personnel
Management, Petitioner v. NAACP Legal Defense and Educational
Fund, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case. Justice Powell took
no part in the decision of this case.
No. 83-2148. Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Klamath Indian Tribe. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion. by Justice Stevens. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.
Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 84-776. Philip S. Carchman, Mercer County Prosecutor, Peti-
tioner v. Richard Nash; and
No. 84-835. New Jersey Department of Corrections, Petitioner v.
Richard Nash. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion

800
TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens
join.
No. 83–1569. Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Petitioner v. Soler
Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc.; and
No. 83-1733. Soler Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc., Petitioner v. Mitsubishi
Motors Corporation. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in
part, and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Brennan joins and with whom Justice Marshall joins except as to Part
II. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of these cases.
No. 84–48. United States, Petitioner v. Hughes Anderson Bagley.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice Blackmun announced the judgment of the Court and de-
livered an opinion of the Court except as to Part III. Opinion by Justice
White concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this
case.
The Chief Justice said:
“Today's Order List includes the announcement of the appointment of
Mr. L. Ralph Mecham as the Director of the Administrative Office of
the United States Courts succeeding Mr. William E. Foley, who retired
in March of this year. Mr. Mecham will assume the duties of the Office
of Director, July 15, 1985. We note for the record our appreciation
of the excellent service of Joseph Spaniol as Acting Director since the
retirement of Mr. Foley.
I am also authorized to announce the retirement of the Clerk of the
Supreme Court of the United States, Mr. Alexander Stevas, as of July
31, 1985. I speak for all the members of the Court, the staff of the
Court, and for the Bar of the Court in thanking Mr. Stevas for his dedi-
cated service and in wishing him much happiness and good health in the
years ahead.
I am also authorized to announce that Mr. Joseph Spaniol, Jr.,
Deputy Director of the Administrative Office of the Courts has been

TUESDAY, JULY 2, 1985
801
appointed Clerk of the Supreme Court effective August 1, to succeed
Mr. Stevas.
I am also authorized to announce that all the cases and other matters
before the Court which were ready for disposition, have been acted
upon by the Court. Accordingly, it is ordered, that those cases remain-
ing on the docket, but not ready for consideration, are to continue to
October 7 next.
The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in Octo-
ber, 1985, at which time the October 1984 Term of the Court will be
adjourned. The October 1985 Term of the Court will begin, as provided
by statute, on the first Monday in October.
I speak for all the members of the Court in thanking the Supreme
Court staff for their dedicated work during the Term."

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JULY 18, 1985
803
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-5. Office of Personnel Management, et al., Applicants v.
American Federation of Government Employees, AFL-CIO, et al. The
motion of National Treasury Employees Union for leave to intervene
is granted. The motion of National Treasury Employees Union to stay
the order entered by the Chief Justice on July 3, 1985, is denied. The
motion of American Federation of Government Employees, AFL-CIO,
to stay the order entered by the Chief Justice on July 3, 1985, is denied.
Justice Brennan and Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these motions.

No. 84-6727. Willie Lawrence Celestine, Petitioner v. Frank Black-
burn, Warden; and
No. 84-6763. Richard I. Dunton, Petitioner v. Department of the
Navy. The petitions for rehearing are denied.
No. 83–1919. City of Oklahoma City, Petitioner v. Rose Marie Tuttle,
etc. The petition for rehearing is denied. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 84–6420. Jimmy Franklin Connor, Petitioner v. Robert James
Haugh, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to file a petition for
rehearing is denied.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, AUGUST 15, 1985
807
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 85-5220. Jay Kelly Pinkerton, Petitioner v. O. L. McCotter,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay
of execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Thursday, August
15, 1985, presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
granted pending the disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of
certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this
stay terminates automatically. In the event the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down of
the judgment of this Court. Justice Powell concurring in the granting
of the application for stay: Ordinarily, I would vote to deny the petition
for writ of certiorari and the application for stay as I find no substance
to any of petitioner's claims. But it is not clear from the votes of the
other Justices absent from Washington, whether there will be four
votes to grant the petition for writ of certiorari, and at this late hour
it has not been possible to clarify their positions. In view of this doubt,
I will vote to grant the stay. The Chief Justice and Justice White would
deny the application. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1985

No. A-32. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human

cate the stay entered by Justice Rehnquist on July 24, 1985, is denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1985
811
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-181. Willie Jasper Darden, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application
for stay of execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Wednesday,
September 4, 1985, presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to
the Court is denied. Concurring statement by the Chief Justice. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Dissenting
statement by Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 85-5319. Willie Jasper Darden, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Upon the re-
quest of counsel for the petitioner, the application for stay of execution
has been considered as a petition for a writ of certiorari. The motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for a writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit are
granted. The order of this date denying the application for stay is va-
cated. The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death is
granted pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court. Con-
curring statement by Justice Powell. Dissenting statement by the Chief
Justice. Justice White, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor would
deny the application.

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1985
813
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 84-6953. Christopher A. Burger, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp,
Warden. The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death
scheduled for Monday, September 9, 1985, presented to Justice Powell
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the dispostion by
this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-941. In the Matter of Margarite Petrillo, Applicant. The appli-
cation for stay addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the Court
is denied.
No. D-489. In the Matter of Disbarment of James P. McGarry. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-494. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Douglas Ed-
wards. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-508. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth Dale Short. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-510. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Cody. It is ordered
that John Cody, of Sierra Vista, Arizona, be suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within forty
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-511. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene A. Stock. It is
ordered that Eugene A. Stock, of Marysville, Washington, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-512. In the Matter of Disbarment of Anthony B. Meisner. It is
ordered that Anthony B. Meisner, of Berkley, Michigan, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-513. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald Dean Nash. It is
ordered that Donald Dean Nash, of Portland, Oregon, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-514. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Alan Lebovitz. It
is ordered that Robert Alan Lebovitz, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,

Gingles, et al. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argu-
ment is granted.

tioners v. Zenith Radio Corporation, et al. The motion of American As-
sociation of Exporters and Importers, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.

College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, et al. The motion of Alan

denied. The motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of the Acting
Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus
curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument
is denied.

Hillery, Jr. The motion of NAACP Legal Defense & Educational Fund,
Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.

:

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1985
849
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-220. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Applicant v. Stephen Todd Booker. The application to va-
cate the order of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit, dated September 9, 1985, staying the execution of sentence
of death, presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court,
is granted. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan joins. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the
application to vacate the stay.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1985
851
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 85-5466. Willie Lawrence Celestine, Petitioner v. Frank Black-
burn, Warden. The application for stay of execution of the sentence of
death scheduled for Saturday, September 28, 1985, presented to Justice
White and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the dis-
position by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the
petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of this
Court. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.

1
(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1985
853
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-235. Three Mile Island Alert, Inc., Applicant v. United States
Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al. The application to continue the
stay entered on June 7, 1985 by the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit presented to Justice Brennan and by him referred to
the Court is denied. Justice Brennan would continue the stay pending
the timely filing and disposition of a petition for writ of certiorari.
